summary: Strange events plague a young woman (Daveigh Chase) and her best friend (Briana Evigan) when their car breaks down on a cross-country road trip.

An atmospheric psychological thriller, S. Darko is a bit inexplicable but eminently fascinating.  Seven years after her brother's death Samantha Darko runs into Roberta Sparrow's grandson while traveling to L.A., and is called upon by forces from the beyond to help him close a tangent universe that threatens to destroy the world.  The film does an interesting role reversal by taking the perspective of the Manipulated Dead; as it's the spirit of Dead-Samantha that guides Sparrow.  And, in keeping with the Samantha character, the tone and visual style incorporates a fantasy-esque theme.  Starring Daveigh Chase, Briana Evigan, Ed Westwick, and Elizabeth Berkley, the casting is fairly good.  However, the script is poorly written, and lacks the sophistication and cleverness of the original.  Additionally, while the soundtrack complements the mood and tone of the film, it doesn't feel characteristic of the mid-90s.  S. Darko is a stylish and intriguing thriller, but it tries too hard to compete with Donnie Darko and ends up being overly convoluted.
The S. stands for SUCK

Having never understood the hype surrounding the original Donnie Darko (I did enjoy it, it just didn't impress me all that much) I came into this one with only one expectation: a cheesy made for TV spin-off, which according to the reviews I read beforehand was one of the worst movies of recent years. Those reviews are wrong. This is a well made, entertaining film with all the style of the original. It essentially retells Donnie's 'Living Receiver' tale from the perspective of the 'Manipulated Dead' (Frank the Bunny) to give the viewer a new perspective on Roberta Sparrow's book on time travel. The only thing that is missing is a character to really root for - you want Donnie to succeed in the original because he's such an interesting character, but Sam Darko turns out to be a bit of a bore. If you're one of the many people who loved the original Donnie you probably won't like this because of the lack of such a character, but if you were lukewarm on it then this one might make you look at the first movie in a new light.

It's pretty easy to see why this sequel to the beloved Donnie Darko is so widely reviled. While I absolutely love its predecessor, I cannot deny that I enjoyed S. Darko...for all the wrong reasons. The storyline is goofy and aloof, the acting is on the level of porn acting, the special effects appear to have been stolen from 80's and early 90's films, the dialogue is absolutely terrible (Especially when the characters blurt out the most bizarre non sequiturs), and the film jumps all over the place. It's an utterly nonsensical film, but it's a camp classic that is waiting to be discovered because it is B-movie gold that made me laugh more than a lot of comedies I've seen (I laughed so hard at some points that I actually had tears in my eyes because some scenes were so gut-bustingly funny). It's a miserable failure as a sequel to Donnie Darko, but it is a film I hope one day gets the attention it deserves as a B-movie classic.

Awful and pointless sequel to the superior horror suspense cult hit, Donnie Darko is a film that never should have been made. The film has a poorly written script, bad directing and a very poor cast. This film doesn't have anything good going for it. Painful and unwatchable. This sequel is a mess from start to finish, and it doesn't have the psychological tension that the first film did. This is a poor sequel that should never have been made. The director crafts a sloppy film and with a poor cast and script, it's clear to see why as a psychological horror film, S. Darko fails miserably. There's not a shroud of creative integrity here and simply put this sequel is a slap in the face to the great psychological horror flick, Donnie Darko which was released in 2001. This is a film that is definitely not worth your time and you should check out the first instead. Director Chris Fisher clearly lacks any directing flair, and can't grasp the material that was established so well in the original. There's nothing worth seeing in this to really make it stand out. All this film is is an exercise in awful filmmaking. This is a clichéd piece of trash that fans of the first should definitely avoid. If you're looking for poor filmmaking then look no further than S. Darko. The biggest problem with this film is that it tries too hard at outdoing the original, but fails and in doing so; we have a film with a cast that deliver bad dialogue, and a very poor plot. There's nothing here that will please fans of Richard Kelley's psychological horror Cult classic.

While it's clear that there's a lot of love for the original infused into this film, there's actually an overabundance of it: not only do some of the events in "S. Darko" pay homage to the first movie, but many of them are simply carbon copies or cheap imitations of iconic scenes. The concepts from "Donnie Darko" that have been duplicated here lack the soul and spine-chilling heaviness that pervaded throughout the original film. It's unfortunate how hollow these images play out once devoid of all unique flair and purpose.

I mean, sure, the effects are passable, and some moments even get a little creepy. Hell, even the acting isn't horrendous (in fact, the characters are so good at playing completely clueless douchebags that you're fine when misfortune befalls them). But with the story lacking substance and with plot holes the size of Utah's Mormon population, this is an undeniably ugly attempt at continuing the pedigree.

For the rest of my review, please check out my movie review blog: http://filmsallthetime.blogspot.com/2012/07/brians-review-s-darko.html

In other words it was just a way to make money and nothing more.

The style is fine...very reminiscent of the original.  Unfortunately, this has no appreciable plot.  The dialogue is heavy-handed, and the montage at the end with the main characters all doing the same thing (in the first movie, lying awake, often crying; in this movie, staring at the sky in fear and wonder), while consistent in style (again), feels forced.  I can't write any more than that without including some very serious spoilers, but I will say this:

The sacrifice made in the first movie prevents a lot of tragedy by disrupting the flow of events to come.  The sacrifice in this movie, however, prevents nothing, as the events in question are already happening when the main characters arrive in town.  The sacrifice makes no difference, whatsoever, it just changes the players' roles in those same awful events.

As a huge fan of 'Donnie Darko', I was expecting a total train wreck from this movie. While it is not even in the same league as the original, 'S. Darko' had a few things going for it. I'll compare this sequel to the original in much the same way I view 'The Blair Witch Project' to 'Book of Shadows' in that it works if looked at as a companion rather than a direct sequel.  
 
It captured the feel and authenticity of its predecessor for the most part, and tied in alot of its history and mythology. Plenty of negatives, as the acting is mostly mediocre. (a strong performance by Daveigh Chase nothwithstanding) Ed Westwick is truly awful as is to be expected.
 
I felt it tried to do way too much. Too many subplots going on which are never really explained and it never seems to reach the climax it should. The writing is solid and the film offers an interesting and creepy vibe.

SPOOK-A-THON!
October 2011

REVIEW #:001

S. DARKO [2009]:  Eight years after the 2001 Cult movie phenomena of DONNIE DARKO this 2009 straight to DVD sequel was made. Unlike the original film, the film was not made or written by the original writer director Richard Kelly was not involved with this film at all. S. DARKO or better yet Sequel DARKO sees the late Donnie's kid sister Samantha Darko now 17 years old in the year 1995 with her friend travelling across the state of Utah after her Family has broken up after Donnie's bizarre and horrific death. Upon getting stranded in a small town, Samantha starts to sleepwalk just like her brother instead she becomes a haunting vision for a disturbed Gulf War veteran called Iraq Jack who she convinces that the world will end in four days. When a meteor narrowly misses Jack, the same bizarre stuff that occurred in the first film again reoccurs in this film with the same ending as the first film.

 No were near as bold and original as the DONNIE DARKO, this film borrows way too much from that film but at least it isn't that bad. To hardcore fans of DONNIE DARKO this film will be too much for you to swallow, my rating is a simple 60% for this film.
i thought this movie was just ok. i did not like how it seemed like they got a do over. and it left u with more questions then answers but it is was not bad.

As a huge fan of 'Donnie Darko', I was expecting a total train wreck from this movie. While it is not even in the same league as the original, 'S. Darko' had a few things going for it. I'll compare this sequel to the original in much the same way I view 'The Blair Witch Project' to 'Book of Shadows' in that it works if looked at as a companion rather than a direct sequel.

It captured the feel and authenticity of its predecessor for the most part, and tied in alot of its history and mythology. Plenty of negatives, as the acting is mostly mediocre. (a strong performance by Daveigh Chase nothwithstanding) Ed Westwick is truly awful as is to be expected.

I felt it tried to do way too much. Too many subplots going on which are never really explained and it never seems to reach the climax it should. The writing is solid and the film offers an interesting and creepy vibe.

Not very well executed, which is unfortunate since it has quite a few actors in it that I like.  The plot is rather lackluster and the characters are underdeveloped and 2 dimensional (which is made sadder by the fact that the writers spent 6 months watching Donnie Darko over and over again to try and get all the aspects and rules of the film right).  This movie truly tries to be like the original, but fails quite miserably.  Not a total dud, but when you compare...and don't kid yourself, you will...this one has got NOTHING on the original!

Everyone knew this sequel wouldn't be as good as the original, but I can say the the director and writer tried REALLY hard and knew their material. Not as bad as I had imagined, but not as good as I had hoped. You could do a lot worse (i.e. Boondock Saints II). Only for fans of Donnie Darko though. Rating: 6/10

Tried too hard to be as good as Donnie Darko.  Some sequences were horribly staged and rather than having a "cool retro vibe" (like Donnie Darko achieved) it had a comedic retro vibe (much like The Wedding Singer).  

The special effects weren't bad and the acting even wasn't that bad.  In my opinion it was mostly the direction and dialogue during the "dream sequences" that came off very very cheesy in a desperate attempt to be weird and creepy.  The dialogue in the other scenes was so over-exaggerated in trying to be "emo" that it was almost laughable.  I almost think that even an "emo" person would be smothered by how thick they laid on the cheesy "my life is so messed up in this cruel world" one-liners one after the other.  

This felt like a misinterpreted continuation of the original concept (in Donnie Darko) rather than a 2nd perspective of it.

When Donnie Darko was originally released on DVD, the film sparked such a firestorm of interest that nobody (including the production studio) had seen coming. Released to theaters in 2001 and blending a fantastic tale of time travel, loss and rejection; the original film received widespread critical acclaim and had the instant makings of a cult classic. Personally, I've seen Donnie Darko on more than 5 occasions since it's release (theatrical and director's cut) and consider it to be one of my 25 all-time favorite films. I know there are plenty of folks out there that despise the film (my stepdad being one of them), but every time I watch Richard Kelly's creation, I've come away feeling one stop closer to understanding the core of the story. I've always felt a film's lasting appeal through multiple viewings is one of the greatest achievements in filmmaking, and Donnie Darko still stands as a perfect example.

Unfortunately, I'm not here to talk about Donnie Darko and you're clearly reading this review with an interest in the 2009 sequel, S. Darko. It's a dangerous game to make a sequel to an iconic film with a cult following; since you run the risk of alienating the fan base with a sub par film - and turning away the uninitiated that may stumble onto this release with zero knowledge of the original film. As a big fan of the first film, I approached this release with equal parts hesitation and excitement at the thought of continuing the intricately woven tale that began with Donnie Darko. Sadly, the results were not what I was hoping for.

The story picks up 7 years after the events of the prior film, with Donnie's sister Samantha (Daveigh Chase reprising her role) on a road trip to Los Angeles with her best friend Corey (Briana Evigan). The two girls find themselves stranded in the town of Conejo Springs when their car breaks down along the highway. Shacking up in a dive-motel, Corey befriends a local tough guy named Randy (Ed Westwick) who promises to fix their car when he has a free moment (which proves to be difficult given his propensity for beer and partying). Plagued by nightmares since the death of her brother, Samantha finds herself waking in odd places throughout the town, and a strange man known as Iraq Jack (James Lafferty) believes she's a princess that's been appearing to him at night with predictions of the world's destruction. In addition, there seems to be a kidnapper in the town, since at least two young children have disappeared in the months leading up to Samantha's arrival. The townspeople suspect Iraq Jack (James Lafferty) of the crimes, but Samantha begins to develop her own suspicions about some less than savory characters that cross her path. In case you were wondering, there's also an element of time travel, but I'll refrain from going into further detail since I can't honestly explain the filmmaker's intentions in a cohesive manner.

After watching S. Darko, it becomes painfully clear why the film was released straight to home video. The lack of a coherent plotline is the driving force behind my dislike for the film and I was a bit let-down by the amateurish nature of the entire production. Donnie Darko was a low-budget film, but Richard Kelly's story managed to pull you in from the very beginning and hold your undivided attention without the use of flashy special effects. I've always delighted in films that keep the viewer in the dark, or force you to draw your own conclusions about the plot (the films of David Lynch are a perfect example), but S. Darko doesn't even have a foundation on which to build. It seemed as though the filmmakers watched Donnie Darko - couldn't understand the film, and decided to make a sequel using a mishmash of elements from the first film. On the bright side, the atmosphere plays tribute to the original film with the same creepy synthesized voice-over, and the happy-go-lucky tone that's interwoven with a pervasive sense of dread; but a cheap knock off is still a cheap knock off.

The worst aspect of the film is the incorporation of time travel, which kills the entire experience on multiple occasions. I'm bothered by films that use the old-age "thank god, it was all just a bad dream" trick, and S. Darko manages to pull that stunt twice (except time-travel is the cop-out in this case). My other disappointment is the incorporation of tidbits that are only added to please fans of the first film, but offer no value in furthering the story. I'm not giving anything away by mentioning that Iraq Jack turns out to be Justin Sparrow (son of the author that wrote the time travel book mention on several occasions in Donnie Darko), since it's completely meaningless to the overall story of this film.

Moving on to the acting in the film, get ready to be disappointed again. I wasn't looking for a high caliber of acting in this straight-to-video sequel, but I certainly thought it would be better. Daveigh Chase has proven to be a promising young actor in her role on the HBO series "Big Love" (I'd highly recommend the show if you've never seen it), but her acting in S. Darko is a little uncomfortable to watch. Perhaps she had a tough time accepting her leading role status, or she just couldn't identify with the character, but her mannerisms and line-delivery made me feel that she wasn't ready to tackle the role of Samantha. The rest of the cast doesn't fair much better, but I think that was largely due to the one-dimensional way each character was portrayed in the story and not entirely the fault of the actors.

S. Darko isn't a miserable way to spend a couple of hours, but it's certainly frustrating. If you consider yourself a fan of Donnie Darko, you'll likely feel cheated by the lack of a cohesive plot and come away from the experience with resentment toward the creators of this sequel. In many ways it's like being sold tickets to an AC/DC cover band, and then finding out the band doesn't even know the words to the songs. I had hoped S. Darko would be handled by a group of creative individuals that understood the charm and intricacy of the original film, but it's clear that's not the case.

Donnie Darko is one of my favourite films. Sadly, I cannot say the same for the sequel, and understand why the director of the original (Richard Kelly) refused to be involved in any way with the making of a sequel.

To explain - Donnie Darko is an extremely well thought out film, with everything seamlessly tied together at the end. And although it is also complicated, it does make complete sense to those who ponder endlessly over it. Everything is perfect. Sadly, this is not the case with S. Darko.

It seems Fisher has taken the basic elements from the original film - time travel, a complicated plot, and the future trails - and exploited them.

Let's take the future trails: he uses them more often than he should, and makes it seem on a couple of occasions that they are alive (they react to the person). Although it is fine to interpret these things differently, as a viewer, I did not think it worked.

The whole thing seems yet another film about a misunderstood, mopey teenager, which we have seen enough of in Twilight. Although Donnie in the original film was mopey, the audience were also led to believe he was slightly mad. In this film, the main character is simply dislikeable.

One final flaw - the special effects resemble something out of Smallville. They make the film so much less believeable, and prevent the viewer from becoming lost in the universe, as they were in the original.

If you are a huge Donnie Darko fan, I highly suggest you skip the sequel altogether.

So what was good about it? Well little Sam Darko (Chase), now 18 has grown up a lot and is really quite hot in an innocent way. Her friend Corey (Evigan) is also pretty hot. The scenary is quite pleasent also. 

And that's about all.

If there was no Donnie Darko then this might be a passable 50%. The storyline by itself could have worked but it was like trying to fit a square peg in an undersized round hole. There is simply nothing at all eerie or spooky about two hotties in skimpy clothes (an attractive but very cheap trick), a gay looking policeman, two bible bashers and an Iraq veteren. In fact, except for Darko herself none of the characters are explored and she is barely. Lafferty as Iraq Jack perhaps puts in the best performance aside from Chase.

Donnie's film worked as it took the totally mundane and made it weird. Samantha's was set in somewhere that could be weird and with people who could be weird but just ended up being boring. There was zero of the interesting nerdiness of the first film either. 

It's hardly surprising that the director of Donnie Darko wanted nothing to do with this and only Chase from the original cast returned. It's not the dire, terrible film the critics make it out to be, and I would encourage you to watch it once. But it had an impossible act to follow and failed miserably.

I remember how, at the end of this movie, I literally sat and took an hour to try and piece together the twisted, freakish mindbomb of a story I had just watched.  Being that I like the sort of thing that makes me think, I was pretty satisfied with what I'd seen.  

At this point, I know a lot of people are wondering how I could possibly have even sort of liked S. Darko.  Here's the thing - I somehow managed to miss Donnie Darko altogether.  I think it came out before I would have been interested in this sort of movie.  By the time S. Darko came out, that had been rectified.  So one night my brother and I were hanging out with a good friend, watching movies.  He had a pretty nice selection of stuff I hadn't seen, and I was vying for Evan Almighty.  Needless to say, I complained heavily when my brother and our friend chose to watch the sequel to a movie I hadn't seen.  They told me to shut up and just watch it, or leave.  So I watched it.

So the whole story of the movie got my mind working, and I was willing to look past the questionable (at best) acting and directing.  I also resolved to watch Donnie Darko as soon as possible, which happened to be several months later when I stumbled upon it in my brother's Netflix instant queue.  

Here's the breakdown on my score for this movie.  I really liked S. Darko when I first saw it, and likely would have given it closer to 100% had I not later watched Donnie Darko.  Since watching the first of the two movies, I still sort of like S. Darko, but now I realize that it was more of a rehashing of ideas already expressed in the first movie.

Okay, Was this movie Donnie Darko? No, not by a long shot. Was this supposed to be? No, not by a long shot. The point of this movie was to show two things, the effect that Donnie's life had on his family, which it did. Samantha was clearly scarred by it and was afraid to hold anyone too close. Secondly, it was supposed to show that Donnie wasn't alone. That the use of portals was a choice not to be taken likely, that history repeats itself to the unwise, and only by owning your mistakes and recognizing what was/wasn't your responsibility can you make a positive change in the world.

This film met those two goals just fine. I took 20% off because of kinda bad (not horrible, but not award-winning) acting, and bad directing. But if you stop trying to compare this to its predecessor you'll see the movie for what it is. While Donnie Darko was about alienation, love-loss, and trying to to the right thing, this movie was about change. Changing yourself, changing those around you, growing up, and seeing yourself for who you are, were and could be. 

There's a reason why it's called "S. Darko: A Donnie Darko Tale", rather than "Donnie Darko Returns" or "Donnie Darko: This Time it's Personal!". It's a story about someone who was in Donnie Darko's life, but Donnie's life actually have very little to do with the plot, it just influenced his sister's perspective which led to the decisions that brought her to the events in this film.

Take the movie for what it is, not for what you wanted it to be.

This movie lived off of Donnie's fame in the most insulting way possible. The "main" character had the personality of zero, a sad attempt at trying to make someone relate to the suicidal, low self-esteemed teenage cocktease. Then halfway through the movie, the main characters keep changing and a few plot lines are intertwined in less than impressive ways. The moral was presented in a weak way and trippy scenes were semi-pathetic.

When Donnie Darko was originally released on DVD, the film sparked a firestorm of interest that nobody (including the production studio) had seen coming. Released to theaters in 2001 and blending a fantastic tale of time travel, loss and rejection; the original film received widespread critical acclaim and had the instant makings of a cult classic. Personally, I've seen Donnie Darko on more than 5 occasions since it's release (theatrical and director's cut) and consider it to be one of my 25 all-time favorite films. I know there are plenty of folks out there that despise the film (my wife being one of them), but every time I watch Richard Kelly's creation, I've come away feeling one step closer to understanding the core of the story. I've always felt a film's lasting appeal through multiple viewings is one of the greatest achievements in filmmaking, and Donnie Darko still stands as a perfect example.

Unfortunately, I'm not here to talk about Donnie Darko and you're clearly reading this review with an interest in the 2009 sequel, S. Darko. It's a dangerous game to make a sequel to an iconic film with a cult following; since you run the risk of alienating the fan base with a sub par film--and turning away the uninitiated that may stumble onto this release with zero knowledge of the original film. As a big fan of the first film, I approached this release with equal parts hesitation and excitement at the thought of continuing the intricately woven tale that began with Donnie Darko. Sadly, the results were not what I was hoping for.

The story picks up 7 years after the events of the prior film, with Donnie's sister Samantha (Daveigh Chase reprising her role) on a road trip to Los Angeles with her best friend Corey (Briana Evigan). The two girls find themselves stranded in the town of Conejo Springs when their car breaks down along the highway. Shacking up in a dive-motel, Corey befriends a local tough guy named Randy (Ed Westwick) who promises to fix their car when he has a free moment (which proves to be difficult given his propensity for beer and partying). Plagued by nightmares since the death of her brother, Samantha finds herself waking in odd places throughout the town, and a strange man known as Iraq Jack (James Lafferty) believes she's a princess that's been appearing to him at night with predictions of the world's destruction. In addition, there seems to be a kidnapper in the town, since at least two young children have disappeared in the months leading up to Samantha's arrival. The townspeople suspect Iraq Jack (James Lafferty) of the crimes, but Samantha begins to develop her own suspicions about some less than savory characters that cross her path. In case you were wondering, there's also an element of time travel, but I'll refrain from going into further detail since I can't honestly explain the filmmaker's intentions in a cohesive manner.

After watching S. Darko, it becomes painfully clear why the film was released straight to home video. The lack of a coherent plotline is the driving force behind my dislike for the film and I was a bit let-down by the amateurish nature of the entire production. Donnie Darko was a low-budget film, but Richard Kelly's story managed to pull you in from the very beginning and hold your undivided attention without the use of flashy special effects. I've always delighted in films that keep the viewer in the dark, or force you to draw your own conclusions about the plot (the films of David Lynch are a perfect example), but S. Darko doesn't even have a foundation on which to build. It seemed as though the filmmakers watched Donnie Darko--couldn't understand the film, and decided to make a sequel using a mishmash of elements from the first film. On the bright side, the atmosphere pays tribute to the original film with the same creepy synthesized voice-over, and the happy-go-lucky tone that's interwoven with a pervasive sense of dread; but a cheap knock off is still a cheap knock off.

The worst aspect of the film is the incorporation of time travel, which kills the entire experience on multiple occasions. I'm bothered by films that use the age-old "thank god, it was all just a bad dream" trick, and S. Darko manages to pull that stunt twice (except time-travel is the cop-out in this case). My other disappointment is the incorporation of tidbits that are only added to please fans of the first film, but offer no value in furthering the story. I'm not giving anything away by mentioning that Iraq Jack turns out to be Justin Sparrow (son of the author that wrote the time travel book mentioned on several occasions in Donnie Darko), since it's completely meaningless to the overall story of this film.

Moving on to the acting in the film, get ready to be disappointed again. I wasn't looking for a high caliber of acting in this straight-to-video sequel, but I certainly thought it would be better. Daveigh Chase has proven to be a promising young actor in her role on the HBO series "Big Love" (I'd highly recommend the show if you've never seen it), but her acting in S. Darko is a little uncomfortable to watch. Perhaps she had a tough time accepting her leading role status, or she just couldn't identify with the character, but her mannerisms and line-delivery made me feel that she wasn't ready to tackle the role of Samantha. The rest of the cast doesn't fair much better, but I think that was largely due to the one-dimensional way each character was portrayed in the story and not entirely the fault of the actors. 

S. Darko isn't a miserable way to spend a couple of hours, but it's certainly frustrating. If you consider yourself a fan of Donnie Darko, you'll likely feel cheated by the lack of a cohesive plot and come away from the experience with resentment toward the creators of this sequel. In many ways it's like being sold tickets to an AC/DC cover band, and then finding out the band doesn't even know the words to the songs. I had hoped S. Darko would be handled by a group of creative individuals that understood the charm and intricacy of the original film, but it's clear that's not the case. Those of you who've never seen Donnie Darko should go rent that film instead, or take a leap of faith and blind purchase it.

Iraq Jack was the only character I thoroughly enjoyed, and the ending left you wanting a little bit more. Unlike the first one, whose ending had purpose and left you feeling strangely fulfilled and happy with life, this one left off everyone's lives in turmoil.  Anyway, it's worth a see for Darko fans, but it will definately be hit or miss;  There will be something in it for you, but most likely not enough to save the movie.

here is his review -
"
S. Darko has the look and feel of Donnie Darko. I liked how the story was both a logical followup, plus a fresh reversal of Donnie Darko's personal time travel predicament. Woefully, the execution could've been much better. None of the characters and ideas were fleshed out well enough. I didn't care enough about the characters to grieve their sacrifice; I wasn't moved to tears like I was at the end of Donnie Darko. Some characters were downright annoying and some unbelievable. What was with the geeky meteorite-boy; was he influenced by the space rock or was he always a creep? (BTW - nice Jeff Goldblum impression!) Recklessly, there were too many characters and storylines tossed around - and not enough connective plotting to tie everything together like the masterpiece original. I liked some of the subtle references to the first Darko, but others were curiously forced; like the metallic rabbit mask and the Time Travel book. Worst thing of all was the setting was no longer in the magical 80's, so they played 1995 tunes; which took me out of the serious moments. 
"

This is a horrible mindless regurgitation of images and ideas from the first film. Really, just save your time and skip this. Actually, don't even read the rest of this review. It actually resorts to completely rewinding itself not once but twice. Worst of all is that fact that after finally reaching its conclusion it actually has no internal logic. Donnie's sacrifice at the end of the original film resolved the paradox. There is no indication that the actions at the films conclusion will change anything regarding the apocalypse at hand. To the film makers I say, "you bought the rights to the film, is this really all you could come up with? Why even bother?" The film gets a tiny bit of credit for resurrecting Catherine Wheel's "Black Metallic" but overall even the soundtrack fails to resonate in any way similar to that of the previous film.

There is a fundamental problem when a different director, along with different writers try to elaborate on such an original idea.  Richard Kelly's Donnie Darko was a masterpiece, it was a dark, chilling story about time travel, parallel universe and the end of the world, and yet found time to include a subtext about existential teen angst and alienation.  All of the lead and supporting actors did a wonderful job, the incorporation of pop songs was the best I've seen for any film, and the cinimatography was excellent.  And the movie, while confusing, wrapped itself up nicely at the end.

S. Darko, on the other hand, plays out more like a piece of fan fiction than a proper sequel.  It borrows all of the superficial plot elements of the original film  and rehashes them into a new movie. While I have no problem with the idea, that Donnie's younger sister encounters similar events as her brother, the film doesnt really say anything new.  A good sequel should elaborate on what came before, and make things a little clearer.  While the events of the first film are mentioned, they are never really elaborated on.  No light is shed on Donnie's fate.

If Donnie Darko had never been made and this was the first one, then I would give it a better rating, the movie isn't terrible.  It is interesting, although it doesn't come together at the end like the first one.  It just that when you begin to borrow key scenes and dialouge (even the same voice) from the orginal film, you begin to look like a hack.  There are even numerous camera angles and fast forward/rewind sequences that are directly copied (for instance the party scene in the first film, which was an important scene, is copied for this film, except the party serves no real purpose.  It is just filler).   There is also the reapperence of the rabbit, but it has been taken out of context and seemed also placed in just to carry it over from the first film.  Once again, I have no proble with that, except hey never explain why its there (if you see this film, you will know why they need to explain it)

But it seemed like it was an honest effort to continue the story.  But ultimatley its a failed one

Direct-to-video sequel to 2001's "Donnie Darko" is a far cry from the cult classic status it's prequel has earned.  Here's Samantha Darko (Daveigh Chase, "The Ring") is now 18 and having a bit of a sleep issue after her brother Donnie was crushed by a falling plane engine in the first film.  So she runs away from home with her BFF Corey (Briana Evigan) to head cross country.  They break down in East-Nowhere-Bumfuck where the meet Randy (Ed Westwick) who drives them into a small town where all the fun begins.  Maybe "fun" was a poor choice in words.

Things start off slowly with Samantha NOT having similar visions to her brother, but instead her herself being the vision in the eyes of an Desert Storm vet named Iraq Jack (James Lafferty), who's looked upon as the town weirdo.  If you understood how the first one works, and who Frank the bunny ended up being, you'll know exactly what's gonna happen to Samantha.  Thankfully when that does happen, the film is only halfway through, so then we're given another plot involving a murdered kid, Corey's visions, and a bunch of other random, nonsensical stuff.

It's kind of like the "everyone has a dark secret" from "Twin Peaks" meets a "Donnie Darko" TV series pilot.  Except you could easily make this into 2 or 3 episodes of a series.  On the other hand, the filmmakers watched "Donnie Darko", completely misinterpreted it, and made a foul smelling sequel.  The events & themes of the original aren't just rehashed, they're done in the WRONG sense.  "Donnie Darko" has confused many people on what exactly is happening.  This sequel is director Chris Fisher's idea (though I'd put more blame on the writers) of what HE thought "Darko" was about.  The problem is he's wrong.  The original film is 100% clear if you pay attention, and made even more clear in the Director's Cut.  Fisher is obviously one of 40% or so that had no idea what was happening in the original.

What we have here is a smorgasbord of "how many references can we make to the original?".  Copy the music score as closely as possible without a lawsuit?  Check.  Have a character drive Frank's red car?  Check.  Reintroduce Frank the Bunny?  Check.  Wait...what is Frank the bunny doing here?  Had the original made any sense to the filmmakers here, they'd realize  Frank the Bunny was a bunny because of the Halloween costume.  It served a purpose in the original film involving FRANK.  His bunny outfit and the reason behind it was explained away at the end and no one else but Donnie should anyone dressed like that.  That is unless Frank gonna come speeding into this movie and run over Gretchen Ross again.  To make this more clear, it's along the same lines as having the bullet time effect in anything BUT "The Matrix".  There it served it's purpose, other films, it's just copying it cause it "looks cool".  Same for here.

On the other hand, it's nice to see Daveigh Chase return as Samantha Darko (though she has little to do outside of reacting to everyone else) and I thought everyone else did an alright job.  The acting itself was never a burden on the film, nor were the effects which are done just as well as the original.  Elizabeth Burkley of "Saved By the Bell" and "Showgirls" has a small meaningless role in the film...that actually has MAJOR meaning...except it's never emphasized.  And the great John Hawkes ("The Perfect Storm") appears to do what he does best: play a counter jockey running the motel, something he did better in "Identity" and also equally as good as the liquor store clerk from the opening scene of "From Dusk Til' Dawn".

Hardly any credit can be given to director Chris Fisher as his direction isn't his own, but how close he can come to duplicating Richard Kelly's direction from the first film.  He succeeds in copying most of the sped up shots and angles, mainly clouds moving and the party scene (complete with a person on a trampoline wearing a Halloween mask of an ex-president...pointless when this film takes place on 4th of July weekend).

And for those non-faithful believers out there, midway through the film things get super religious as if stopping to say "And now a message from God".  Religion isn't just mentioned, it's screamed at you as if trying to convert you.  This isn't the first time that's been done.  Check out the "Left Behind" films which are financed through churches (so that's where the money in those donation baskets goes to!) or even "Starship Troopers 3", another film which is preachier then your Sunday Mass.

The film's nothing but an attempt to cash in on the cult classic success of the original, but without Richard Kelly at the helm, one can't expect much.  The use of the budget seems to be done just fine and doesn't affect any aspect as it's flaws lie in the script. I had heard a lot of bad reviews about this movie but before I could judge I had to check it out. Donnie Darko was one of the greatest movies I had seen, so I didn't expect much out of this sequel. However, I found S. Darko to have a great story line and I loved how they created it. You have to look at this movie as a stand alone film and forgot about the first one Donnie Darko to be able to truly enjoy it. Yes, it is nowhere near as good as Donnie Darko and it lacks some of the true meaning of the story line. However, if you view it as keeping with the concept it struck perfectly. So, if you are going to watch this movie expecting another Donnie Darko you will be disappointed, but if you feel optimistic and take time to enjoy the S. Darko story line as its own new story you will enjoy it.

Now this is A Donnie Darko "Tale", so if you want to give it a fair chance then it is important to watch this with no expectations of comparing it the original film.  I feel this is a great continuation by an outside director that has built upon a cult classic.  It was dangerous for them to tamper with the original but I give them credit for trying something that is known to be taboo in the film world.  They were smart about it and didn't just make a sequel which allows it to be appreciated.  Daveigh Chase does a great job at developing upon the unknown character of Donnie's little sister and its fortunate they were able to use the same actress.  It is visually beautiful with great shots of the mid-west and has a soundtrack that is euphoric from beginning to end.  I recommend you give it a second chance if that's what it takes for you to get over the fact that Donnie Darko is a much better work of art.

s. Darko wasn't nearly as bad as I thought it would be, but that still isn't saying much. I love Donnie Darko as it seems to be a film that gets better with each viewing. When news that a sequel to the film was being made, the question that plagued me and every other person who was a fan of the first film was, "Why?" Did the original really leave much room for a sequel? Not in my eyes. The sequel does little to add to the story established in the first film. It pretty much treads the same ground. The world is going to end again. An element that is different in the film is that more than one person is having the visions this time around. While it makes sense that Sam is having these visions, it doesn't really add up why these other people are having them as well. The movie does a lot of back tracking. A lot of things are explained only to rewind and have it play out differently, which makes full use of the time travel element of the film but kind of leaves the viewer wondering if the film was nothing more than a waste of time once the ending rolls around. The film just seems to recycle most of the ingredients of the first film (time travel, Frank the Bunny...even though he's not Frank this time around, religion playing a roll in the film, black holes, etc) and is unable to establish itself as a decent sequel, let alone its own film.

The scene in Donnie Darko that has "Head Over Heels" by Tears For Fears playing in the background while we see Donnie arrive at school and the "Mad World" scene are really the first scenes that come to mind when I think of the original film. The soundtrack played a pivotal role in the film. In s. Darko, there isn't really a scene like that and the soundtrack is forgettable, which really only hurt the film in the long run.

s. Darko walks a thin line between paying homage to the original film and complete bastardization. Its plot tries to string the viewer along this intelligent and thought provoking story, but executes doing so in clumsy fashion. It resembles a circus seal waiting for its reward after playing that ensemble with its nose on the horns currently residing in front of it. It'll really only be accessible to people who were fans of the first film, which is ironic since the film will probably just wind up irritating those fans. If you can ignore the first film entirely and have no expectations for this, then you may find yourself with a direct to video release that is...pretty much just that.

As a huge fan of 'Donnie Darko', I was expecting a total train wreck from this movie. While it is not even in the same leauge as the original, 'S. Darko' had alot going for it. It captured the feel and authenticity of its predicessor for the most part, and tied in alot of its history and mythology. Plenty of negatives, as the acting is mostly mediocre. (a strong performance by Daveigh Chase nothwithstanding) Ed Westwick is truly awful as is to be expected. I felt it tried to do way too much. Too many subplots going on which are never really explained and it never seems to reach the climax it should. The writing is solid and the film offers an interesting and creepy vibe.

I tried not to be too prejudicial or harsh on this film, but yeah, this film falls waaaay too flat. It has all of the style, but none of the substance of the original film, coming off as a fan-film by a starrey-eyed ametuer who has all the admiration, but none of the understanding of richard kelley's work.  I can admit, that there were some parts that I found good, and the soundtrack is great, but ulitmately, the film could have used some originality by just ditching entirely the time travel and rabbit and Donnie Darko copies, and making Samantha her own character instaed of just a pale copy of her brother.  Or just creating new and original characters.  Or having characters with ANY sort of redeeming interest at all.  Or by just not making the film period. This film is bascily a dime-store rush-produced empy copy of the original, nothing more.

Ma allora - al di lÃ  di un certo piacere masochistico e della prospettiva di godere di 2 ore di aria condizionata - perchÃ© bisognava averne conferma in prima persona?

Si puÃ² fare qualcosa a livello legale per fermare chi si impossessa delle figure del nostro immaginario e punta a rovinarle? Non ho mai visto Blues Brothers 2000 per non deturparmi l'icona sacra di Jake ed Elwood. Per fortuna S.Darko sfiora marginalmente il primo film raccontando la storia della sorella di Donnie, Samantha (interpretata dalla stessa ragazzina - ormai cresciuta - dell'originale) e quindi puÃ² essere considerata una cosa talmente lontana da non avere ripercussioni sul primo e unico vero capitolo (forse un po' sopravvalutato, ma comunque intrigante) firmato da Richard Kelly.
 
Stavolta il regista Chris Fisher butta dentro qualche ingrediente conosciuto dai fan: c'Ã¨ l'icona del coniglio, c'Ã¨ la scena tra le poltrone del cinema, ci sono le canzoni anni '80, ci sono i cieli attraversati da nubi in corsa. Ma mancano la poesia e il fascino misterioso del "primo appuntamento". Quasi ogni scena Ã¨ accompagnata da un pianoforte o dagli archi in modo tale che finiscono per non notarsi piÃ¹, mentre ad esempio le note di Gary Jules sottolineavano il climax di Donnie.
Addirittura in questo capitolo (in America uscito solo in dvd non a caso) tutti muoiono, rinascono, viaggiano nel tempo, rimuoiono per salvare qualcun'altro. Alla faccia della Filosofia dei viaggi nel tempo. A tal punto che si fatica persino a capire chi sia il vero protagonista del film.
 
Stendiamo un velo pietoso sulla recitazione: l'amica di Samantha ("interpretata", per cosÃ¬ dire, da Briana Evigan) ha livelli di espressivitÃ  talmente scarsi da suscitare risate (per non parlare del "figo" di turno con sigarette arrotolate nella manica della t-shirt). Certo la scrittura dei dialoghi non aiuta e la regia sembra quella che potrebbe fare un teenager dal basso quoziente intellettivo che in tv ha visto solo i peggiori videoclip di 20 anni fa e non ha idea della nozione di "ritmo".

Skeptisim abound for this, arguably, unecessary sequel to the original cult hit, S. Darko sees Daveigh Chase (now nicely grown up and filled out) return to the role of Donnie's younger sister, finding herself haunted by visions and events strikingly similar to those suffered by her brother.

The film manages to capture the look, feel and abiance of the original, while telling a slightly different, and, if possible, even more warped story based on the rules established in the first film.  While overaly a positive experiance, however, there is that lingering feeling that it does not quite measure up as highly, but the viewing experiance does not detract or diminish the quality of the original movie in anyway, so it's worth a look.

De deux choses l'une : Ou vous n'avez pas encore vu Donnie Darko et vous pouvez franchement vous limiter a ce dernier, meme si l'histoire de la petite soeur, son atmosphere etrange et son excellente B.O. peuvent exercer une relative fascination sur le neophyte durant la premiere demi-heure.  Ou bien vous avez deja apprecie a sa juste valeur le film-culte de Richard Kelly et cette tentative de creer une franchise vous donnera juste l'impression d'avoir perdu deux heures de votre vie.  Pour parler franchement, S.Darko est une piteuse copie conforme qui reprend consciencieusement la construction et les ficelles de son modele sans parvenir a leur conferer la moindre forme interessante.  L'effet de surprise est evidemment absent et par manque d'imagination, certaines trames secondaires sont superflues et ne servent qu'a embrouiller vicieusement le spectateur.  La complexification maladroite des possibilites quantiques du scenario rend en outre le tout vachement bordelique et incoherent.  Deja qu'une suite, meme reussie, ne s'imposait pas reellement : dans le cas present, on est clairement dans le domaine de la Pigeon-Xploitation.

You could argue that Donnie Darko was a pointless movie and that there could be no good reason to like it.  But I did like it.  I thought it was clever, and I guess that was point enough for me.  This one was more of the same, but without the cleverness.  On top of that, I couldn't really figure out what it was about.  Vaguely spooky stuff happens.  Cute girls go back and forth in time to undo their own deaths, but wind up dead anyway.  So do a bunch of peripheral characters.  There's a drunk guy who never seems drunk, a nerdy guy who's really a serial killer (I think), and Rambo (how'd he get in this movie?).  Uh, okay, so what?

Since I can't bring myself to believe the producers just stamped out S. Darko for no reason, I'll tell myself they made it so middle-aged men could lust over the scantily-clad maidens therein.  And in that respect, it was good.

Have you seen Donnie Darko?  This is the same movie.  Same bunny, same creepy dream sequences, right down to the portal that represents predestination.  But there is no mystery, no guessing, no ah-ha moments, no explanation, no Noah Wiley, no Mad World cover - just a predictable sequel with some fringe actors from Gossip Girl (who actually does a good job acting) and One Tree Hill (who plays a cliche nerd that is on a par with Disney Channel acting), Elizabeth Berkley (supposed to be a Christian zealot - can you say overacting?), some WWJD petafile (the boyfriend from Legally Blond).  I find it hard to believe that of all the original Donnie Darko fans, there is not a better script out there for a sequel. I'm still trying to make sense of this time sequence that jumps around like Sammy Hagar in an inflatable playground.

I expected this to be complete crap, but it was slightly better than that. It's not great or even good, but it's not terrible either. If I would've seen this in theater (if this had made it to theaters), I would've said I hated it and it was terrible. As a straight-to-DVD movie, it manages to be mediocre. I've seen MUCH worse movies make it to theaters and MUCH worse movies that were straight-to-DVD. Basically, my view is that it could've been worse, but it still wasn't good either. That being said, I hope the rumored third movie doesn't happen.

If you liked Donnie Darko you'll enjoy the sequel. Of course Donnie's gone, so this story is about his youngest sister (which I must admit I didn't expect). I suppose some of the acting isn't up to par, but it's easily overlooked when you consider the sheer imaginative power that went into it.

Utterly pointless and mostly-boring rehash of the best concepts from Donnie Darko, handled very badly. Darko's 'weird' elements worked because Richard Kelly set up so cleverly the world in which they existed. Whilst S. Darko expects us to accept them just because. Weirdness for weirdness sake doesn't work, particularly when the plot and characters just aren't engaging. This film's minor release will hopefully prevent it from further tainting the Darko name...

It's a sequel to a movie that never, ever needed a sequel and it's every bit as bad as you'd expect it to be.  It tries very hard to emulate Donnie Darko but, despite borrowing some of the more obvious ideas, seems to understand nothing of what made that movie so great.  The result is a series of meaningless moments that bear no relation to each other and a movie that spends about fifty of its alotted ninety minutes ending.  Very slowly.

There are mild upsides.  Elizabeth Berkley puts in a surprisingly decent performance as a crazy religious woman and the film definitely gets points for using Catherine Wheel and the Cocteau Twins, even if the specific songs chosen aren't that great.  It's not much, but, you know, it's something.

Another pointless sequel. Its funny how the people on the 'making of' on the dvd try to validate the reasons for this film becoming a reality. Its not technically a sequel, it's a "continuation." Or, "a continuation implies a saga, a sequel implies trying to recapture something from the original." I'm pretty sure that's exactly what they did here, since the movie plays out nearly the same as the first. Lots of angsty teens (even one that looks too much like Jake Gyllenhaal), a shady pastor who's playing the Patrick Swayze role, and the biggest "name" in the movie was a child actor. So just imagine a VERY low budget remake.

Ok, so just like in the previous movie, someone was supposed to die when an object fell out of the sky. Since they did not die, now there's a 'ripple in time' and the movie is about trying to go back in time and reset everything so that they do die and everybody else lives happily. But then that happens HALF WAY through the movie. Now we go through the same sketchy time travel process again.

Absolutely retarded sequel to the weird and wonderful Donnie Darko which is likely to leave fans bored, annoyed, and very disappointed. While the filmmakers have made a decent stab at imitating the superficial aesthetics of DD, this follow-up lacks any of the subtlety, charisma and most importantly intelligence of the original. While Donnie had an eerie and almost baffling sense to it, its curiosities were nevertheless meticulously considered, purposeful and founded upon robust mythological principals - all of which were threaded into a highly compelling narrative. The makes of s. Darko are completely out of their depth however and don't seem to have understood their original subject at all. The plot is abysmal, hackneyed and everything that Darko was not, lacking any degree of substance or sense. This film should never have been made.

First of all, Donnie Darko is one of my favourite movies of all time if not my favourite, hearing about the sequel like most fans of the first movie I was very worried about the second instalment, how can you repeat perfection? You canât. But that doesnât mean that you should avoid it like the plague right?
Donnie Darko was the complete package, from the story right down to the soundtrack, it had it all.
I canât say there has been too many times in my life that once the credits have started rolling straightaway you hit play again and still be in oweâ¦thatâs the Donnie Darko experience. It never getâs repetitive. It never gets boring.
Taking all of this into consideration and after reading some awful reviews I braced myself for the worstâ¦to S Darkoâs credit the worst never came, some elements of this movie were very tight, the backdrop for the movie is breathtaking for example, some of the ideas are decent but itâs some what overshadowed by the ambition to be more clever, more mind-boggling and more tasking on the brain. Itâs almost trying to hard to be accepted by fans and it becomes the movies major downfallâ¦Do you need so many layers? I actually like the fact that no matter what was changed the boy was still going to die (or at least thatâs how I see it) if you didnât know better youâd almost say that this was some sort of vanity project.
Iâm staggered to find out that Richard Kelly wasnât involved with the process or by the sounds of it even consulted?  His vision and direction would have been need for this to have any chance to add to the legacy of the first.
I think a better idea would have been to ask the fans to come up with some ideas, to use the passion people have for Donnie Darko and I believe the movie would have been better for doing soâ¦   
I also think Frank was such an integral part of the first movie and itâs seems to me as if  âheâ is only giving a token partâ¦why wasnât the Frank we know and love brought back? 
although not as bad as I feared I still think they should have left Donnie Darko as a stand alone masterpiece, Iâm sure most fans of Donnie Darko have sat down at some point and made their own story up in their heads on what happened after Donnie sacrificed himself, I almost feel like my own story has been taking away, feeling a little robbed. The beauty of Donnie Darko is it left it open for you to decide for yourself.
S Darko may get better with time, and a second viewing Iâm sure wonât be far away but I think they could have explored better avenues, personally I wouldnât have gone down the Samantha route but Cherita Chen for me would have been a more interesting story to tell.
Itâs hard to score this movie, I wanted to love it despite the critics panning it and knowing it wouldnât hit the heights of the first. All in all not great but Iâve seen a lot worstâ¦hopefully next time will be better.

So i finally gave in and rented this movie last night. Being a huge Donnie Darko fan, i was very hesitant to hand over my 4$.  The movie is set in 1995 Utah, 7 years after the death of Donnie. Sam(Daveigh Chase), Donnie's little sister stars as a lost 17 year old who is on the road with her best friend Corey(Briana Evigan, Step Up 2) when their car breaks down in nowheres-ville Utah. After meeting the entire town in a day, strange events occur which all unsurprisingly mimic the plot line of D. Darko. 
  Despite the low budget graphics, and poor story line; the movies cast really shines through in the film. Jackson Rathbone(Twilight) absolutely amazed me with his role as the nerdy Jeremy.  Likewise Daveigh Chase, who was also in D. Darko, was seductively inspiring with her come back role as Sam Darko. 
   So with this review i give this movie a "Rent" 3 out of 5.

Ohh God, I don't even know where to start on this piece of shit. I have an instant bias against this movie because it is nothing but half-assed straight to DVD cash cow, trying make some more money on hardcore fans of the first film. I loved the first film, but i downloaded this, and yeah i feel bad for anyone that paid money to see this. All this movie does is take plot devices and conventions from the first film and recycle them MULTIPLE TIMES and they try to rationalize it into a significant plot. The thing that is most frustrating about this movie is that it doesn't focus on any one character. It focuses on several people having the same delusions that Donnie had and it just makes it feel cheap and not unique. You would think since the they brought back Deveigh Chase from the first film that Donnie's sister would be the focus, but she isn't at all, she is has equal screen time as about 3 other cliched characters. The only thing I like about this movie is the small homages it pays to the first film, and even those are cheap. The movie should have focused on Iraq Jack, cuz at least he somewhat resembled Donnie. The indie cult classic "Donnie Darko" was an ingenious, imaginative tale about teenage angst incorporated with time travel, schizophrenia, and devotion. Darko Spoiler Alert! Darko Spoiler Alert! Darko Spoiler Alert! OK, enough. Donnie dies in "Donnie Darko" in his free-will time travel flight to deviate the powers of destiny. Well, time has passed since Donnie Darko's closed chapter. So I am dumfounded why the powers that don't see, decided to visit the Darko sequel side. "S. Darko" follows the travels of Donnie's younger sister Samantha in an incongruous, insubstantial way. There was no reason to play it again with Sam! Daveigh Chase does play it again portraying Samantha. But this time she is not the bratty 10 year-old she was in "Donnie Darko". Samantha is portrayed in "S. Darko" in her late teens as an adventure-seeking drifter doing some road trip time travel of her own with her BFF Corey. Their car breaks down in a small rural town, and before you can say "here comes another rabbit test", the infamous "Frank the Bunny" appears, but not in the same surreal way as in the original Darko. Only his loose head appears in this sequel and becomes an earmark symbol within the strange ordeals that occur in the rural town. Director Chris Fisher and Screenwriter Nathan Atkins try to reincorporate all the original Donnie Darko elements in "S. Darko" but to no avail. The Atkins diet of light scribing and the Fisher direction of bait-less audience man-trappings was a Darko catastrophic event that should have been put in a time machine to avoid this cinematic monstrosity. "Donnie Darko" Director Richard Kelly wanted no hand in this sequel and one can see why Kelly shied away, and probably furious upon witnessing the cinematic crime of "S. Darko". Let's now take a little ride in my movie review time travel machine and go back to the "S. Darko" plot (sorry!): Samantha & Corey suddenly come into contact with the small-towners as if they were significant fixtures of their past which includes the archetypical: cool guy, nerdy science guy, hypocritical priest, quirky hotel manager, ruthless cop, and maniacal young veteran. The ensemble acting of "S. Darko" also did unfortunately demonstrate the dark side of abysmal thespianism, with only Chase as Sam and Elizabeth Berkley as religious zealot Trudy giving mediocre turns. Donnie Darko is probably rolling in his time-machine grave in witnessing the dummy darko of "S. Darko". 
* Failure

The writer and director obviously did not understand the first film, and took this second one in a very "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" (the series, not the movie) sort of direction.  Suddenly everyone is special, everyone can see their future, they all get visions, and second chances, and blah blah blah.

What made Donnie Darko so special is that he -was- special.  Now suddenly because someone wants to make a sequel, everyone in the world gets his powers. I really wanted to like this movie.  I really did.  Honest.  I loved Donnie Darko, in fact its my favourite movie, so I approached this with the knowledge that so many sequels, no matter how hard they might try, often fall way short of the mark and leave a sour taste in your mouth.  This was slightly better than expected, but still fell short of being a decent film.

On a postive note, the cinematography was superb.  Outstanding even.  The score was also first class, probably better than Donnie even.  Sadly it fell short in other more important areas, such as empathy for the characters, decent acting and the fact it was too similar to Donnie.  It tried to be too serious.  It tried to out-Donnie Donnie.  Donnie had a great humourous edge to it.  This was more like the film equivalent of a morgue.  Many things didnt make sense.  What was the point of the jesus loving lady?  Or the Donnie Darko rabbit mask?

Whilst it had its good points, as a whole it can be added to the list of dissapointing sequels.  Whilst almost passable, and certainly a hell of a lot better than other sequels such as Blair Witch 2, given how good Donnie Darko was and how complete a movie it was, this was always going to be fighting a lost cause.

Give it a shot... much like Screamers 2: The Hunting, it may not have any of the cast or crew in common with the original, but it does a good job of emulating the original without retreading the same ground.  Mainly it's based on the fictional book The Philosophy of Time Travel from the original movie, and a working knowing of that brief text makes it much more enjoyable.

I find it rather amusing the fans of the original say things like "it's exactly the same as the first"... which just proves that they didn't see this one and are complaining to hear themselves complain.  There are similar elements, but those are spelled out in the aforementioned TPoTT text, and a part of the mythos of these events.  

Another rather lame complaint is the acting, and yet that's obviously done to emulate the original creator's style, and not a reflection on the ability of the cast.

So, don't be a hater... see it with an open mind and you'll probably like it.  My copy sits on the shelf proudly next to the original... I only wish more US films were this strange.

A classic example of where fans of a film who clearly don't understand either it or filmmaking in general attempt to create a piece of fan fiction which either badly recreates moments from the original or is just incomprehensible.

The worst of its many crimes is its faliure to create a proper sense of place. Donnie Darko was grounded in the social quagmire of the late 80s. S. Darko could take place anytime, anywhere, and there isn't a single character in it who you wouldn't want to see obliterated by a meteor by its end.

S. Darko picks up 7 years after the end of Donnie Darko, and his younger sister, Samantha (played once more by Daveigh Chase), is encountering her own alternate reality, only this time she is a manipulated dead (taking the 'Frank' role) guiding a washed out ex-soldier to stop the world from ending.  Pretty much more of the same as last time around, with little attempts at referencing the original by way of names (there is a Frank who runs a garage, and the soldier is surnamed Sparrow... linking with Roberta Sparrow who wrote about time travel in the first), as though that will somehow lift the mess above the level it is at.  It doesn't!  The film attempts to blatantly rip off key moments from Donnie, such as 'burn it to the ground', or poorly concieved reasons for rabbit shaped masks, but seems to do it just for the sake of reference rather than having any point of purpose to the story.  One of the most memorable moments in the first film was the 'Head Over Heels' introduction to the school, beginning with a spiral shot away from a school bus, and then following Donnie through the school halls.  What made this scene so special was not just the music, or the 'fast-slow' direction, but the fact that it used 2 minutes of shot to introduce all the key characters in Donnie's school life without any dialogue, but in such a way that we know everything we need to know about their personalities.  Well, in S.Darko a similar shot is used to walk through a party, but for no reason of introduction of character, simply just to rip off an iconic scene.  Throw in someone jumping on a trampoline, and it is at this point that you realise this film is offering nothing new, no build on the original at all.

As a standalone film the story makes little to no sense.  Donnie Darko at least was written by Kelly with a definite idea as to what was happening and why, even if it doesn't quite explain everything.  All the clues were there if you dug down into examining every scene.  With this film it seems to be deliberately written to make no sense at all, and the time manipulation used throughout is weak and unexplainable.  As for the resolution (which sees another rip-off moment as we see the lives of those affected throughout played past in slow motion to music), it leaves no hint of resolution, or teases of ideas for you to care about.  So, on its own merits this film is badly written, as a sequel it is diabolically bad!  Donnie Darko had you leaving the theatre caring about what you saw, and trying to formulate an idea about what occurred.  S.Darko has you wondering what else you can watch to take your mind off it!

If this film has any use it is in allowing us to re-examine Donnie Darko and realise exactly how well made the film was.  It even allows those who were not enamoured with Southland Tales to perhaps see that film in a different light, as compared to this Richard Kelly's second film was a work of art!  This was always going to be a tough sell of a film, as a sequel to such a cult success.  Perhaps they should have renamed the lead character and attempted no link with Donnie.  At least then it would just be a straight-to-DVD piece of trash, as opposed to one which tried to latch itself onto the coat-tails of greatness.

Pales in comparison to it's predecessor.  It's the direct-to-video sequel to Donnie Darko, a movie that I'm a fan of, but not a rabid fanatic like so many of it's follows are.  None of the main players are back except for Donnie's little sister, Samantha, who, if I recall correctly, didn't have that big of a roll in the original.  It focuses around her and her best friend when their car breaks down in Podunktown U.S.A.  There they meet the confident cool guy, the sarcastic police officer, the insane war veteran and other stock characters.  The rest is all an imitation of themes of the original; rabbit masks, water-air and apocalypse predictions.  There are two things that really took me out of the movie, and that is the very bad acting and some of the special effects.  I know it's direct-to-DVD, but that's no excuse not to place forth an effort in acting.  Granted, they are given lots of bad dialogue to deliver, but still.  Ed Westwick as the cool kid was the sorest thumb of the bunch for me.  Some of the CGI effects look very out of place; the photography is actually much better than you would expect, and director Chris Fisher should have more confidence in that so that he wouldn't have to fall back on such fake looking effects.  Lots of scenes feel like music videos, and he is probably a really good music video director, just not a good movie director.  It's slightly better material than your standard direct-to-video movie, but still completely unnecessary.

Straight to DVD movies make me nervous since it is almost a guarantee that the film will suck... epically suck.  "Midnight Movie" was a prime example of straight to DVD suckage.  And just like "Midnight Movie", "S. Darko" suffers from the same fate.  It sucks.  It sucks epically.  It sucks so bad, it's almost painful.  The worst part is that this is supposed to be a sequel to "Donnie Darko".  I don't even want to call it a sequel to "Donnie Darko", because every time I do it kills me inside.  How could this piece of crap be a sequel to the cult classic?  It hurts me to think about it.

It isn't widely known that "Donnie Darko" was destined to be a straight to DVD movie.  I bet a lot of people who didn't know that are probably thinking, "Whoa, really?".  But yeah, it's true.  "Donnie Darko" was originally intended to head straight to DVD.  So you can imagine my thought-process going into "S. Darko".  I figured "Hey, 'Donnie Darko' was gonna go straight to DVD, so why not give 'S. Darko' a chance? It might turn out great!".  Wrong.  Dead wrong.

Essentially every aspect of the original film is reduced, reused, and recycled in "S. Darko".  The creepy bunny?  Reused.  The liquid spears coming out of people's bodies? Recycled.  The twisty ending? Reused (TWICE! TWICE IN THE SAME MOVIE! ARGH!).  The message and the character developent? Reduced and reused.  I honestly feel like I could list EVERYTHING from Donnie Darko and it would somehow appear in this... bastardized film.  If you're going to make a sequel to a movie, why is it necessary to reuse so so so much of it?  Thankfully, they didn't just revert to using clips of the first movie.  I understand a sequel should rely on some aspects of the original (in terms of storyline, characters, etc. etc.) but it's really not enjoyable to watch this movie when so much of it feels ripped from the first.  There's nothing really original offered here.  The closest we get to something novel would be the more heavy handed religious aspects and the sub-plot involving a creepy pedophile priest (yet even that is ripped from the first, considering the whole sub-plot of the child porn ring).

There really is nothing in this movie worth checking out.  The gist of the movie is that Samantha Darko (Donnie Darko's little sister) is all grown up and rebelling against her family by running away from home with her extremely skanky best friend.  The two end up in some backwards town on their way to California and decide to shack up there because there's "gonna be a house party" at some guy's house.  Who the hell decides to live in a town for an extended period of time in order to attend a house party with a bunch of strangers?  I guess it was just the director's excuse to include a house party scene (once again reused from the original! Ugh!).  From there on, it pretty much just continues in the tradition of the original, except the girls sleepwalk around town so frequently it becomes absolutely ridiculos.  There must have been at least 4 or 5 instances where the girls stumble around town in their shorty shorts and barely there tank tops.  In all instances they hardly arouse a twitter from the locals.  I guess they must be used to half-nude ladies wandering the lonely streets of their quiet little town at 3AM.  Eventually there's a whole double sacrifice thingy, where both girls end up dying for the sake of each other (or something along those lines) until eventually the town nutjob/essential bunny suit man goes back in time to save both of these little twits.  The end. Yawn.

Before I end this ranting rampage, I have to mention how HORRIBLE the director/writer of this movie is (Chris Fisher... fucking asshole of Hollywood).  The script is laughable.  It sounds like a bunch of stoners having a pseudo "deep" conversation.  Example: "I wonder what God's farts taste like?  Marshmallow Peeps?"  I did some research and it turns out Chris Fisher is best known for director episodes of crappy TV shows like Cold Case or Moonlight, and for writing the scripts for movies about serial killers and gang-bangers.  Wonderful.  I'm not sure how a guy who once wrote a script involving gang-bangers  and directed a movie about a notorious rapist  was hired to write/direct the sequel to a cult classic coming of age horror film.  I guess they're giving anyone the right to ruin the classics these days so long as they have the ability to use a laptop and hammer out a script that's not even worthy to wipe your ass with.

Well, I know a lot of people did not like this film, mostly the die-hards for the original but I must say that this movie was not near as bad as I thought it would be.  In fact, I would even consider it worth watching.  

The homages it pays to the original are numerous and the fact that this movie takes place 7 years after the original and this movie was also released 7 years after the original is a nice touch.  It gives you the reverse side of things from Donnie Darko, Sam is the manipulated dead instead of the manipulated living.  I also believe that this film will attract a younger audience to the original so that's a good thing.  

That being said, it does have its problems, this one isn't near as slick as the original or thought provoking, it's just a re-hashing of the same ideas the original presented.  You can tell that it didn't have near as much budget as the original as well from the very first frame.  And it certainly deserved a much larger budget.  However, I believe that the director did the best he could with what he was given and I have to give him some props for that, saying that if I were a director I would have never taken this movie.   

All in all, I have to say that I did enjoy this movie and that fans of the original should probably give this one a look, at least a rental.  And please Hollywood, let's try not to make a third one unless Richard Kelly directs it and a decent amount of money is put into it.

Man, I wish I could enter a wormhole, go back in time and not watch this movie!! It is by far the most incoherent movie I have seen in quite some time. It had great potential, and definitely left one guessing like D Darko, but it was too jumbled together. Too much going on and not enough explaining. For instance, one of the main characters in the movie goes looking for Samantha Darko at her hotel room as the 'world is ending', he shortly gives up and the movie jumps scenes, shortly later the character shows up on a hilltop many miles away where Samantha is, promptly picks her up off the ground and exits stage right. No explanations. It's OK though, the movie reverses it's self several times and has several 'main' characters that have a very limited involvement in the film. There's is hardly any character development for several of the characters, so there's is none of the connections that D Darko enabled the viewer to form with the characters. There is frequent use of the various fundamentally Darko elements (the bunny, wormholes, time travel, strange sleep-walking scenes) but that is all that connects it to the Darko movie and the only elements that I think give any quality to this film at all. It was just not thought out very well, and definitely not filled out well.The tone of the movie is also drastically different than that of the first.

It's not as bad as you may think.  It's just utterly pointless.  Essentially what the filmmakers have done is tell almost an identical story to Donnie Darko, just with Donnie's sister as the main character.  If you understand Richard Kelly's time travel talk, then the big twist in this movie is that Samantha is not the Living Receiver, like Donnie was.  She plays the role of the Manipulated Dead, or the role of Frank the bunny from the first film.  
It's a well made film.  And Ed Westwick pretty much plays his Gossip Girl character here, which is always entertaining.  But the film takes no risks.  The filmmakers seem too concerned with making their film feel like Donnie Darko, that they don't explore the mythology in any way.  The film is too safe, and as a result, is as forgettable as a bad meal.

The movie s. Darko: A Donnie Darko Tale has a completely different vibe to it compared to the original movie Donnie Darko.  
From the original movie, the main character Donnie had a somewhat super hero attitude feel to it; while the second movie is more of a fairy tale; dealing with the main character Samantha.  Even the creators (who are fans of the first movie) say that the second movie is more of a ?continuation? rather than a ?true sequel.?
Since the two movies are based in two different time periods (1988 and 1995) and also two different main characters; it is to be expected that they are not going to feel the same.  
I personally admire the hard efforts that the people who had created this movie.  I also hope to see another continuation within the universe of Donnie Darko by either the original creators, the people who made the second installment, and/or by more fans of the original movie who want to expand the world of Donnie Darko.
My closing comments: The footage that they shot in Utah is beautiful, the movie is a little more simplex compared to the original, but for people who never saw the original movie and don?t really care to watch a movie that wants to make people think might become more easily hooked with this movie rather than the first movie.
