I love the original Donnie Darko so much and was excited to hear about the sequel, S. Darko.  I was a little nervous because I had read a few negative reviews, but I wasn't really disappointed.  In fact, I was quite thrilled.  With the exception of an awesome soundtrack (a big plus from the original), this sequel is 99% as good as the first, but in a different way.  There's enough content on this movie to contemplate and decode for some time to come (it's been years since seeing the first Darko movie and I still think about it from time to time).

I think I would really like to go back and watch both back-to-back as there's information revealed in the first film which is referenced in the second.  I don't think you can really appreciate either film without looking reading some of the background material, checking out the websites, and spending a little time comprehending the mythos in the Darko universe.  

Personally, I would LOVE to see a prequel to these movies covering the creation of the Philosophy of Time Travel book and what led granny Sparrow to help set all these events in motion.

Anyway, to those who said S. Darko was bad are probably just negative people who like to whine about everything haha..... (j/k)

This sequel, starring the little girl from the first movie now all grown up, is way better then it had any right to be. Every single complaint I hear about it, from fans of the first movie, are the same complaints you hear about the first movie from people who didn't like THAT one. Hard to understand? Hell no, not if you actually understood the first movie. Compared to the first, this one is easy-peasy to understand what's going on.

However, its far from perfect. Some of the performances were good, but others were meh, and it seemed they threw things in pointlessly to tie more into the first movie - such as the Bunny mask which served no point at all in this movie. And I'm not quite sure how the one dude sacrificing himself at the end like Donnie did in the first movie, prevented the Earth from being destroyed this time around, as the event that happened in the Tangent Universe would still happen whether that guy is alive or not, and it left a couple things unanswered, such as who was locking the kids away in that dungeon.

But it did do some new things, such as having TWO tangent universes (A tangent universe within a tangent universe), and switching who the main characters are part-way through was very interesting. Also, the main character this time around was one of the Manipulated Dead

Overall, not only did it not suck as bad as I was expecting, but it also was actually pretty good. A nice little continuation of a cult classic that most people just don't want to give a chance.

Full of pointless throwbacks to the old film, relies entirely on its following, constantly referencing back to it yet failing to explain anything. Lacks any vague form of originality, and any relatable let alone likeable characters. 

Cinematography is dull and uninspired, lots of slow tracking to sad music that will never match Mad World from Donnie Darko. Performances are tolerable, mainly from the side characters, two leads are nice to look at but not much in the way of acting. Ed Westwick seems to have a large pole wedged up his smug arse the entire time, either that or he was going for cool and managed learning impaired. 

Plot has no purpose, a great deal of the film is completely pointless and only serves to add to the eeriness, which isn't there to begin with. There was a lot of potential for this, they could have done something interesting with this universe, well Richard Kelly could have, this guy thought he might be able to, but hasn't. Instead what we get is a predictable, lack lustre excuse for a plot, half of which is basically a loose rehash of the original, but without a quarter of the compelling characters or themes.

It's one thing to love a film enough to want to work with that intellectual property, it's another thing to butcher it and pretend you achieved something. Straight to DVD is right. Pointless Self Indulgent Shit.

But I still think it was just average and I'm not jumping on the whole cult band-wagon.

Of all the films that didn't need a sequel, Donnie Darko was pretty high on the list, as the original story was so impressive as a self-contained entity it seemed unlikely that anything else needed to be said.  But of course, Hollywood would make a sequel to a documentary supporting cannibalism if they thought it could squeeze a few bucks out of it, so it is because of this we have S. Darko, the story of Donnie's sister that picks up 7 years later.  Now, while the movie wasn't as bad as I thought it would be, it was still awful;  the time-travel angles that were so brilliant in the first film are repetitive and nonsensical in this film, the inclusion of Frank the Bunny in this film seems blasphemous to the first film in this context, and the number of times the characters manage to perish and then come back makes you not really care for anyone in the film.  I'll give the film a little bit of credit for having twists in the story that I did not expect and I truly believe that the director was trying to reach for some really fantastic concepts, but ended up falling miserably flat.  Just because a really bad idea doesn't end up as terrible as you expected doesn't really make the bad idea any better.

TOTALMENTE INNECESARIA (y algo inesperada) secuela de uno de los filmes mas emblematicos de mi generacion: Donnie Darko. Este filme en lugar de secuela se siente mas como un rework (ni siquiera remake) de la premisa de Donnie, pero en plan chafa. 'S. Darko' sigue la historia de Samantha, la hermana menor de Donnie, que en medio de un roadtrip queda varada en un pueblo. Por supuesto, desde su llegada comienza a interactuar una galeria de personajes extranos (pesimamente escritos y algunos sobreactuados) y a tener alucinaciones del fin del mundo (con efectos especiales marca patito). La historia mantiene un ritmo lento hasta llegar el punto en que pierde toda coherencia argumental y termina en una resolucion estupida. No entiendo la necesidad de la compania que posee los derechos de Donnie de estropear una pelicula casi perfecta e insultar de esta forma el trabajo de Richard Kelly. Afortunadamente este filme se fue directo a video a hundirse en los anaqueles de las tiendas de videos donde con suerte pasara desapercibida.

Loved Donnie Darko, so I figured why not buy this one too. How bad can it be. Well, its definitely as strange, if not stranger, than Donnie. And yes, even though this was never released in theaters, it still kept my attention. The acting wasn't horrible, the story was awkward (expected), and it had some nice hallucinatory, head-trippy imagery. Cinematography was handled well, what with all the sci-fi-ish F/X. Story deals with Samantha Darko, Donnie's sister, and a group of local yokals that fit nicely into the whole bizarre hick town. The appearance of Elizabeth Berkley was a little creepy, oh she of Showgirls fame, who now pretty much has no career. But the younger cast was good, yes, including Briana Evigan's thankless bimbo role. She pulled it off well, even during the emotional car accident scenes. Oh yeah, I don't quite know if I would have picked the guy from One Tree Hill to play the town crazy, but then I realized the WHOLE town is nuts, so it quickly changed my perspective. See it just for the weird factor, and especially if ur a fan of the original.

I liked this movie for the fact that I knew it was a CONTINUING story from Donnie Darko... not a SEQUEL.  A sequel would have been way worse, because it would have been trying to create the same magic as D.D., which it cannot.  But a continuing story allows us to see through the eyes of Donnie's sibling.  It helped that they had the same actress play Samatha as in D.D.  Obviously, didn't have the same effect as D.D., but a sincere attempt to continue the mysterious life of the Darko family..

Futilely hoping for a worthy sequel to the original, s. Darko is a very poor followup to a brilliant movie.  Desparately trying to catch the flavor of the original, similar camera work is used but accompanied by poor acting and insipid plot.  Don't waste your time.
Great movie.  Wish there was more to it though.

Take the masterpiece that is 'Donnie Darko,' and place the entire film in front a mirror.  What do you get?  For some reason, you get ' s. Darko'... Not making sense?  Well, neither does this movie.  I cannot imagine a more thorough job of tarnishing the reputation of an awesome film.  This may get a bit wordy, so I'll just begin with the simple things.  

Acting.  I felt for a minute like I was watching some typical teenage-horror flick rivaling the cheesiness of the 'I Know What You Did Last Summer' series... then I considered the script.  After carefully analyzing this aspect, I had to move s. Darko a little below the teenage-horror flick level to which I previously referred.  The writing was complete garbage.  Donnie Darko thrived by using a perfect mix of deep, eccentric characters along with stereotypical fill-ins responsible for playing specific roles to assist in efficiently conveying the movie's point.  s. Darko, on the other hand, decided to fill the movie with a ridiculously higher number of these predictable 'fill-in' types and (for some reason) decided to make these the STARS of the movie.  No real issues were addressed with the dialogue in s. Darko besides the shallow bickerings of the ignorant high-school characters who go through a slew of typical social situations that have nothing to do with what SHOULD BE the point of the movie.  (Well, not according to Deveigh Chase, who stupidly remarks that the movie is about 'teenage girls learning and growing as people' in the movie's commentary... but we won't get into that yet.)  While the dialogue completely excludes the real point of the movie, it also adds in a bunch of pseudo-relevant crap about Christianity that leads to a subplot involving a perverted pastor and obsessive follower that play no real role in the story whatsoever.  (Besides slandering the name of Iraq Jack)  I'm going to move on now since I could go on forever criticizing the unintelligent trash heap s. Darko calls a script. 

Now getting to the camera-work... I'm definitely not an expert about the filming of movies, but pretty much the most important action scene in the entire movie was an utter failure.  I am, of course, referring to the accident that kills either Samantha or Corey.  When Corey dies, the accident is fine, because it's a simple concept of one car running into another and killing the girl in the passenger seat - we don't need actual visuals to understand this.  However, when Samantha dies, we see a crappy picture of a car running into another, (just the impact site... about 3 square feet in the frame) and then we see Samantha somehow lying behind the car whose passenger side was hit.  This, of course, makes no sense, as the car that was hit would have to have run head-on into Samantha, leading her to flip over the top and land on her back behind this car.  If this were the case, then the car that was hit would need to have hit Samantha before being hit itself.  That would be fine too, since the driver was drinking, but we are later told that nothing was that driver's fault, that the other car came out of nowhere, and that this other car was somehow the cause of Samantha's death.  See how hard this is for me to explain with words?  Yeah, an actual visual of the crash would have been nice.

At this point, nothing about the movie has been great, but to be honest, the acting, script, and filming don't NEED to be great in a movie like Donnie Darko - it's all about the idea being portrayed.  The people making this film were clearly a bunch of idiot fanboys who never really understood Donnie Darko in the first place.  I've already mentioned the actress who plays Samantha not having a clue what the movie was about (none of the actors/actresses seemed to have a clue), but after watching the commentary from the makers of the film, it's clear that they were clueless as well.  First of all, the movie begins by telling us that the story of Donnie Darko was 'just the BEGINNING of the story and the mystery.'  Unfortunately, the makers of s. Darko decided that this 'beginning' needed to be done again (poorly) without adding anything new.  The first Donnie Darko was pretty cut and dry about what needed to be represented when and where to look for clues in the case that we needed them.  The ambiguity in s. Darko is insane.  Since nothing is explained, we're left to assume that:

1.  The meteor shower toward the end of the movie represents the same Universal collision represented by the storm in Donnie Darko.
2.  The meteor rock causes the rash that the nerdy guy (and later the motel owner) had... and this rash causes some sort of personality change?
3.  The children in the mine never get rescued no matter what happens?

In the commentary offered by the filmmakers, they (sort of) stated their intentions.  Samantha was meant to be the opposite of Donnie as far as her wants/needs.  Donnie was afraid of death, but had to face that death in order to save his universe.  Apparently, Samantha is afraid of LIVING, so she has to live instead of die.  For some dumb reason, the makers decided to settle on this concept, but it's obvious that they ran into a real rut.  This was never addressed by the makers, who said that they wanted to raise questions/mysteries in the film that don't get answered... which is just a lazy way of saying they wanted to throw some 'mysterious' garbage in there that makes the movie seem cool but doesn't actually make sense.  But, getting to their rut... (we'll need a new paragraph for this)

In order to stay in tune with Donnie Darko, you can't just mirror the entire concept of the movie and expect it to work.  Donnie had a reason to avoid that jet engine - to live.  Frank (the 'living dead') helped him accomplish this, and that lead to the end.  In s. Darko, the makers WANTED Samantha's death to lead to the end, but this doesn't work, since Samantha would not be alive to time travel and save herself.  So, the makers decided to just make Samantha the living dead (now the living dead is just another character in the movie?!) who saves Iraq Jack.  Clearly, this makes no sense given that Samantha didn't even know Iraq Jack at the time, nor did she have any reason to want him left alive.  So now, the makers thought, "so now Samantha has to die somehow as a result of Iraq Jack's living to do what we wanted to do... but we can't have Iraq Jack be the time traveler because then he would pretty much be the main character in the movie and play the part of 'Donnie.'"

This is where things got complicated.  (and screwed up)  In the original Donnie, it was clearly shown that his death was all that needed to happen to save the universe.  In s. Darko, Iraq Jack needed to technically live AND die for this to work!  Because the movie made so much of it about the social learnings/relationships of the girls, Iraq Jack's dying would not have  had any impact on the fate of the universe without him living first.  Since Iraq Jack needed to live and then die for everything to work out, his living didn't really trigger to end of the Universe... suddenly the count-down was inaccurate and the entire fate of the universe was dependent on the irrelevant co-star (Corey).  In the end, Corey needed to time travel, (which she somehow figured out in a second... completely different from Donnie Darko) and she became the REAL trigger that saved the Universe.  Just to make the story still have something to do with Samantha, the makers had to make her play the 'intermediate' role of time traveling herself to let Iraq Jack die.  So in the end, it was all about Corey dying... but Corey wasn't signaled by a living dead character like Frank, she was signaled by some kidnapped kid stuck in a mine shaft!  Once again, they just decided to take a random character and make this character represent the living dead.  The problem with this is that there was no signal in the film to show that any difference in the past ever changed the fate of these kids.  Had this been shown in some way, the movie might have made a little more sense. (but not much, since we're now really stretching with our assumptions)  To make things more clearly understood, here are the possible scenarios playing out through the movie:

1.  Iraq Jack dies originally - in this case, Sam never learns anything, and neither does Corey.  The church doesn't burn down... but then again, what did the church have to do with the story anyway?  Both Corey and Sam stay in town, and the Universe (probably) ends anyway.  (assuming there's only one way everything works out and that involves Sam leaving town because she's learned from later experiences)  In this case, we really don't have any clue what might have happened.

2.  Iraq Jack lives originally and Samantha dies - the end.

3.  Iraq Jack lives originally and Corey dies - go to scenario 4.

4.  Iraq Jack lives AND dies (ridiculous) - the Universe is saved.

Overall, the makers of s. Darko just wanted to make a mirror copy of Donnie Darko and struggled to throw together a bunch of extra assumptions and crap that makes no sense just to make their unnecessary ideas work.  The entire plot was ambiguous just to protect the mistakes of the filmmakers.  Since s. Darko was simply a mirror image of Donnie Darko, I decided to mirror Donnie's star rating as well.  One big HALF STAR for the disaster that is 's. Darko.'

[i]"Sometimes I wish I could switch places with someone else."[/i]--Samantha Darko, [u]S.Darko:  A Donnie Darko Tale [/u]

This movie has not switched places with [u]Donnie Darko[/u] in my affections.  The title, reminiscent of [u]In the Name of the King:  A Dungeon Siege Tale[/u], should have been replaced by a sleeker title like [u]Samantha Darko[/u].  [u]Donnie Darko[/u] fans would have found and watched a movie of this alternate title, no matter how obscure the advertising.  Instead, this low-budget follow-up to the original film is what is obscure to the [u]Donnie Darko[/u] fan.

Not content to wait any longer to cash in on the success of [u]Donnie Darko[/u], Silver Nitrate Films has done just that because [u]Donnie Darko[/u] fans will watch this picture just as I did.  Why will fans watch this picture?  Because they will be looking for additional layers of meaning to add to the Darko mythos.

After I had watched [u]Donnie Darko[/u] and I understood enough of the plot through fansites to grasp the movie's underlying concepts, I became fascinated with dimensional theory, enough so that I even purchased and read a book on the subject, [u]The Great Beyond:  Higher Dimensions, Parallel Universes, and the Extraordinary Search for a Theory of Everything[/u] by Paul Halpern.  I still avidly follow physicists' developments on Many Worlds Theory to this day.

It was with this desire to continue building on my own theory of everything that I watched [u]S. Darko:  A Donnie Darko Tale[/u], hoping to gain some new insight into our own universe.  I was disappointed that the film, instead of presenting a new vision, simply plays around with the concepts of the first.  The rules, the images and even the plot of the first are recycled to serve the sequel, and this does not produce a fan-pleasing result.

When I saw the trailer, I wondered, "What could this movie possibly be about?" I thought perhaps the movie studio had cast another 10-year-old Samantha Darko who we would possibly follow on her plane ride into the black hole that opened at the end of [u]Donnie Darko[/u].  I saw all sorts of possibilities in what might lie beyond that black hole.  Could such a sequel be done without the original actors if they were necessary?  Maybe if it were animated.

[u]S. Darko:  A Donnie Darko Tale[/u] instead presents multiple bubble universes similar to the single one of [u]Donnie Darko[/u], this time introduced through the emergence of a meteorite, composed of a metal that is alien to the periodic table.  Unlike in [u]Donnie Darko[/u], however, it is unclear to me how the events that unfold in the sequel bring about the introduction of the alien metal into our universe.  Per Sam's quote above that she wished she could switch places with someone else, events in one bubble universe seemingly affect events in another, such as her dying in another's place.

But the movie becomes rather incoherent from there, similar to the devolution of the plot of the movie L[u]ife Force[/u] when the alien entity in that film mentally invades Dr. Armstrong's body.  The second bubble universe presented in [u]S. Darko:  A Donnie Darko Tale[/u] is destroyed by a tesseract shower, and a troubled Gulf War veteran in the film, Iraq Jack, sacrifices himself in order to save our world from the same fate.  Long before this point in the plot, any viewer who has not seen [u]Donnie Darko[/u] would be lost to what is going on, and even I find myself asking now, "How does Iraq Jack's sacrifice save our world?"  I'm at a loss to explain.

By watching this film, I have decided that parallel universes can be a really fun topic to base a movie or series around (e.g. [u]Sliders[/u]), but while [u]S. Darko:  A Donnie Darko Tale[/u] plays around with the mythos of its predecessor, the inclusion of the characters Samantha Darko and the grandson of Roberta Sparrow, the rules of  [u]Donnie Darko[/u] and pretty much a recycled version of the plot of [u]Donnie Darko[/u] were unnecessary for this sequel.  I think it would be far more interesting to present an alternate, parallel Earth to our own where new rules and an innovative plot are presented rather than slavishly attempting to produce something new from the aftermath of [u]Donnie Darko[/u].  The failure of this movie is somewhat analogous to the failure of the film [u]Cube 2:  Hypercube[/u].

A lot more convoluted than DONNIE DARKO. Not sure how many of you know the DARKO lingo, but the sister (played by the original actress Daveigh Chase) represents the Manipulated Dead like Frank did in the original. Put it this way: imagine following the Frank character around for the entirety of DONNIE DARKO. It gets a little complicated because the filmmakers create a 2nd Tangent Universe (with different characters representing the Manipulated Dead and Living Receiver roles). The plot is essentially the same though -- a "Donnie" character (here played by James Lafferty of "One Tree Hill") is saved from death in order to save the world. The problem is we don't really see as much of him as we should. There are some tie-ins to the first film, i.e. a mechanic named Frank. One problem I had was the sister possesses Donnie's book on time travel, which shouldn't be the case since, technically, he received it in a Tangent Universe -- and died in the Primary Universe.

Has some cool moments but far fewer than the original Darko. The lack of cool actors, like the Gyllenhaals & Seth Rogan, and real actors, like Mary McDonnell & Katherine Ross, had a bit to do with this film not living up to its predecessor. The soundtrack was also not close to "Donnie". Now, it's pretty much a given that living up to Donnie Darko was an uphill battle but the fact that this was an absolutely pointless film was its biggest downfall.

FIRST of all. Donnie Darko is one of my all time favorite movies. It has been for a long time now and I have a special place for that slightly flawed but cult classic masterpiece. 

NOW while this film sucked, I assure you that I watched this with a totally open mind. Know this, it's a different cast, different director, so this is pretty much only connected with the first movie via lame light references or the beginning little paragraph explaining the first film before starting this one up. While the story follows the same mind fuck pattern of decisions, time travel, and odd other tid bits, its just soooo damn generic and lazy compared to the first. There is no reason this movie should have ever happened, and as much as I hoped this was going to be at least decent, this is indeed one of the reasons why sequels do not work when the source material was not even suited for sequels in the first place. This is not the worst movie ever or even the worst movie of the year but seriously, what the fuck did I just watch it was like a rehashed half assed version of the first only worse in nearly every single way. Complicated for the sake of being complicated and vague, it is so obviously trying to be different and mind twisting like the first film but it totally isn't, and is insulting at times as much as it is a homage to donnie darko...

The only glimmer of hope that I had for this thing was when a couple unexpected events occured, but they are totally overshadowed by the lame writing and sub par directing and performances so you can't even really give the movie too many points for that.

What's the most ridiculous thing you can imagine happening in a Donnie Darko sequel? Is it Elizabeth Berkley walking around with a book called Jesusonomy? That (and much more) happens in S. Darko, a direct-to-DVD sequel to Richard Kelly's 2001 cult fave. It's more like a spinoff than a sequel. The closest thing I can compare it to is Walter Murch's Return to Oz, which used some of the same characters from The Wizard of Oz but felt completely alien to the spirit of the original.

As the title suggests, S. Darko concerns Donnie's kid sister, Samantha (Daveigh Chase). Seven years have passed since her brother's death (the film is set in 1995). Sam has run away from her home in Middlesex, Virginia, and set off for Hollywood. This backstory is explained in a ludicrous epilogue that I can't resist quoting from: Sam is "seemingly alone and lost in the world." She's "drowning in sadness and unable to dream." Oh, and "when darkness consumes the starlight, nightmares rule the night." Is this movie for real or what?

Sam and her bitchy friend Corey (Briana Evigan) get sidetracked on the way to Hollywood and end up in a bumfuck town in Utah. There, she learns the world will end in 4 days, 17 hours, 26 minutes and 31 seconds. In a place like this, the end can't come soon enough.

Just like that doomsday countdown, there are other "quotes" from the original. Roberta Sparrow's grandson, Iraq Jack (James Lafferty), says "they made me do it" (a phrase Donnie scrawled on the pavement after vandalizing his school). There's a character named Frank (as in Frank the Giant Bunny Rabbit). A portal opens up in an empty movie theater. Time travel plays a big part, as does Roberta Sparrow's book, The Philosophy of Time Travel. And so on. If you think the experience of watching a Donnie Darko sequel made without Kelly's blessing might feel slightly sacrilegious, you wouldn't be half wrong.

The original inspired fierce love and passionate debate. I used to watch it about once a week, and with each viewing, I felt like the puzzle pieces would add up to something even more profound than the conclusions I'd drawn the last time. S. Darko inspires nothing but confusion; it's disjointed and meaningless. It has missing kids, ghosts, a car crash, scenes that double back on themselves -- but none of it connects. It's an insult to Richard Kelly's intelligence.

On the plus side, the film features some witty casting. Chase is the same little girl from the original, now all grow'd up. It's funny to see Berkley (from Showgirls) looking all churchy and self-righteous. Lensing, scoring and FX work are all top-notch. See it if you must, but for me this story ended when David waved at Gretchen in the street at the end of the original -- the ultimate hello and goodbye.

There are multiple problems with this. For one thing, it doesn't follow some of the parts of Donnie Dark correctly (think: Time Travel Elements). And speaking of its predecessor, it copies far too many parts (particularly quotes and scenes) and an excessively annoying amount of allusions to Donnie Darko, making it completely unoriginal.  In many ways, it's another version of Donnie Darko, only without explanations or any sense of connection.  Donnie Darko is brilliantly played out; this is not.  

Outside of its connection with Donnie Darko, there are other things. The acting is awful, the storyline is a mess, and the dialogue is some of the worst I've heard from any movie (the taste of farts? What the hell?). The entire thing is all over the place. It has moments of some potential, but those are never built upon, and so it just stumbles over and over again.

Really, how can you take the elements of an amazing film and make it look like absolute crap?!  Donnie Darko did not need a sequel; just like its storyline, S Darko is pointless.

Donnie Darko fans BEWARE of this movie! As I, you will be tempted to watch this for no other reason then how good Donnie Darko was. When the credits begin to roll, you will also be extremely irritated that you wasted 103 minutes of your life. You will wish you could unsee what you just watched! I knew all about how terribly this film was reviewed and expected very little. Even if I had never seen Donnie Darko and knew nothing of it's connections, it would still be a monumental failure. There are many problems with this movie, but I will save my criticism to the 3 most frustrating. 1st...horrible acting. One of the greatest things about Donnie Darko was seeing great performances out of rarely seen actors/actresses. S Darko showed that poorly written characters + horrible acting= epic failure. 2nd...pointless storyline. What was the point of this movie?? Donnie Darko figuratively transported me inside the movie with it's captivating storyline. Even though I was left with questions at the end of Donnie Darko, I was not asking "why did I waste my time watching this?" 3rd...awful soundtrack. Something I love about Donnie Darko is how well the soundtrack assisted in the telling of the story and the emotions it was meant to induce. S Darko had an anemic soundtrack in comparison. Multiple times during the movie I found myself actually thinking "why are they playing this music right now?" A final note (even though he didn't have much to work with), Chris Fisher should stick to directing TV.

Quando si tenta (con la forza) di bissare il successo di un film cult e' raro che si riesca ad ottenere qualcosa di passabile il risultato sarebbe un film totalmente inutile come S.Darko...
Sorvolando su alcune banalita' e sull'uso smaccato di "belloni" delle ragazzine (tra Gossip Girl, Twilight e One Tree Hill ci mancava solo Zac Efron) il paragone con Donnie Darko non ha assolutamente motivo di esistere.S.Darko parte sostanzialmente dalla base lasciata dal primo film, i viaggi nel tempo e la possibilita' per qualcuno di cambiare il futuro. Qui terminano i punti in comune dato che non ci sono vere spiegazioni ad eventi come la caduta del meteorite o le visioni dei vari personaggi, ma soprattutto percha' c'e' di nuovo in mezzo il coniglio??
In Donnie Darko TUTTO aveva un motivo per essere mostrato, in questo film mi sembra si dia piu' peso all'aria forzatamente(e inutilmente) inquietante di alcune scene e poi la bambolina Daveigh Chase, con tutto il bene, ma non riesce proprio a sfiorare la perfetta interpretazione di Gyllenhaal.
Sorge il dubbio che gli autori di questo film siano tra quelli che non hanno completamente capito "Donnie Darko" dato il risultato del sequel...

This was a huge mistake.  It haphazardly snips at concepts from the original film, applies them all so loosely that all the meanings lose their value.  I really really wanted to like this.  I'll go as far as saying I wanted to love this...but I didn't.  The characters were disappointments, the story was worthless, and the paths this story chose to take were dull and unfortunate.

Awful.  What made the original Donnie Darko so charming was missing from s. Darko.  Gone were the original, quirky, and realistic characters... instead, s.Darko is full of stereotypes (the nerd, the rebel-jock, the rebel-girl, the religious nut, etc.).  s.Darko either tried too hard to be like the original, or didn't try enough.  I couldn't tell if the similarities between the two movies (the burning of the church vs burning of Cunningham's house, Trudy/the preist vs Jim Cunningham, etc) were on purpose, or because of a lack of originality.  None of the acting was nearly as deep or as raw as the original Donnie Darko, and the camerawork was just more of the same.  The scenes with Samantha being a 'Frank' type character were also laughable and horribly lame.

 The story in this follows Samantha Darko played by Daveigh Chase from the first movie as she is dealing with the death of Donnie and the neglect from her parents following Donnie's death. We learn how rough of a time she had and that she attempted suicide a coupple times. The movie picks up where her and her friend are on a road trip going to LA. There car breaks down in a small town and events start happening like in the original. However this tells the story from the manipulated dead's point of view. In the first movie Donnie was the reciver and Frank was the manipulated dead. This story has Samantha being the Manipulated dead and a new character Iraq Jack (played by James Lafferty) who has a closer connection to the original that we might first think. All in all this was actually a really good movie which is going to get hatred simply beacause it's a sequal to Donnie Darko. Although I wouldn't even say it's a sequal more of a continuation. And the award for most unnecessary sequel IN THE WORLD goes to the cash-in direct to DVD sequel to the infinity superior Donnie Darko, S. Darko. S. Darko follows young Samantha Darko (returning Daveigh Chase), who was once a little child that was part of a silly dance squad in the original film but is now a depressed runaway/young hottie who road trips across America with her best friend/supermodel (Briana Evigan) towards Hollywood when their car breaks down in a hick town where they meet an assortment of hot, young characters (starting to see the pattern?). Sure enough, one of the residents is experiencing the same exact stuff as Donnie, only his Frank the Bunny is Samantha who communicates to him in the same voice in an alternate universe. This film is total rubbish. Though it has excellent direction from Chris Fisher, the story is so blatantly a rehash of the same stuff we saw in the original, that it almost seems criminal. Hey guys, I got an idea! Instead of an airplane engine, lets use a meteor (Yes, the steal the ending from the original). Hey, and instead of a flashy sequence of kids and adults mingling in a school environment to the soundtrack of classic 80's music, let's do the same thing, only at a party and with terrible D-grade mid-90's rock. This is a HUGE rip-off film. Also, it insults me when greedy movie-makers cast their films with supermodels in hopes of having viewers not notice the very weak storylines and plotholes. This film was a very clever attempt at making a remake to a new film and calling it a "sequel". Awful, awful slap in the face to fans.

Really now? 
OK, so I decided to rent S. Darko because I absolutely love Donnie Darko--the direction, the acting, the lighting--it was all phenomenal. O never expected a sequel, nor did I ever think the "sequel" S. Darko would ever come close to living up to it.  I watched it like one would watch a train wreck, a plane crash, or a car accident (haha just like the countless car wrecks in S. Darko).  It was a spectacle, something with startling cuts, fast motion, and slo-mo. 

It's a cut-and-paste collage of bad acting, blatant references to Donnie Darko, and ridiculous dialogue. (My Favorite: "Drinking warm beer and dry humping to Journey? Boo-yah!")

There is nothing to see here, people.  Everyone dies at some point in the time warp (Samantha Darko twice, actually).  And SPOILER ALERT Iraq Jack's body is carted away FULLY intact after he is hit with a meteor, ahem, meteorite (Sorry Jeremy).

So, three plotlines (I use that term loosely) are followed.  The only remotely cinematic thing about the movie is some of the lighting and technicolor.  Yeeeahh, it was a disaster.  I just hope Kelly and Fisher didn't take themselves too seriously throughout this production.

It wasn't as good as it should've been, and it wasn't as horrible as it should've been. It's an interesting little movie, it follows Samantha Darko in the mid 90's. Follows the same plot as the first with a few twists. Devalues the original's archetypes and overall meaning.

It's a five-star movie based on expectations, but it couldn't shake the ten-rungs-down-from-the-original feeling for pretty much the entire running time. S. Darko is a decent movie created with great respect for the Donnie Darko world. It doesn't chop anything important to the ground, it doesn't step too far away, but it still creates something that matters. Unfortunately, it also gets really frustrating due to the fact that things aren't tied together very well, and the fact that the original's themes (right down to camera technique) are carbon copied over to the sequel. A few bizarre characters that seemingly have no impact on anything are unwelcome as well. But hey, it tries, and it doesn't suck. Considering the circumstances, I couldn't have asked for anything more.

Terrible.  I'm sorry but let me first start by saying that it's almost impossible, no it is impossible to write and direct a sequel to 2001's classic independent film, "Donnie Darko", yet the powers that be decided we needed a sequel, cause everything needs a sequel right?

The thing that amazes me is that they actually got Daveigh Chase, the original actress who played Donnie's sister in the original film, to reprise her role here.  Does that even come close to legitimizing a sequel, no, no it doesn't.  Let's see, for starters, instead of a child pornographer guy getting arrested at the end, this time we have a crazy religious cult in a small town (I believe it was unnamed, but again I was more mesmerized by how terrible this film was), headed by a dude who's nothing more then a man using the Bible to get what he wants, which is young children.  Disturbing, yes, also uncalled for.  Samantha and her friend are on a road trip, perhaps on the run, who really knows, and they end up in this small town where crazy stuff happens.  Oh and by now, if you haven't seen the original, yeah skip this. In fact I think I'm just going to end ranting on this piece of trash now, and I'm just going to tell you that if you've never seen "Donnie Darko", go rent it and give it a shot, it's an amazing film.  It may take you more then one viewing to understand everything, but that film was awesome.  This, however, is just a cheap cash in on a good film. Don't bother. It only gets 1 star for having decent special effects for a direct to dvd film.

Okay, so this post is specifically directed at all of the Donnie Darko fans out there that are thinking about seeing this film, but are worried about it being a mess...

Sadly, it really can't hold a candle to the original. The production values are actually quite good, so it's at least watchable. Daveigh Chase and Briana Evigan are quite convincing in their roles (but everyone else in the film is terrible). It doesn't _look_ like a crappy little independent project (though the CG is pretty poor). On the plus side, the soundtrack is full of 90's nostalgia, which at least parallels the 80's nostalgia Donnie Darko was full of.

It fails to however, to resurrect the dark, brooding feel of its predecessor. The plot is also riddled with so many holes that it's completely incoherent. In fact, the story just makes no damn sense. Unlike the cleverly symmetrical puzzle pieces of Donnie Darko, S. Darko is just a clumsy, fumbled together mismatch of pieces. To make matters, the story is incredibly uninspired, and the plot is annoyingly similar to that of the first film. Not similar in the sense that it pays tribute to it, or that it is a continuity of it (which it should have been, and could easily have been, but most certainly was not); it's merely a poor imitation.

So I say to fans, it's worth a look if you're really, REALLY curious... but this is pretty much bad as can be.

So I honestly thought that there was no way in hell one could conceive a sequel the to the amazingly awesome "Donnie Darko" but since Hollywood deems it necessary that everything either needs a sequel, prequel, or remake then I guess this was the best possible solution. That and I'm a sucker for franchises. 

Needless to say I did not have high expectations for "S. Darko", being as it was straight to video and the complexity and 'have to watch it a billion times to even catch everything' side of the first film, this was going to be a long shot. But, in the end, I was definitely on the pleasantly surprised side of the fence for this one. 

Fans of the first film (and you HAVE to see it to even begin to crack into this one) are going to find a lot of things to love about this one. It does keep it pretty faithful to the style and approach of "Donnie" with its use of music from the era (this time its the 90s!), the slow and fast motion shots and lots of wacky shit, I still can't wrap my mind on what the hell that glowing feather really is, and of course, the rabbit from hell. I was curious to see how they made the rabbit fit in this time as it was so situational specific for "Donnie" but without giving away spoilers, they made it work.

At times, I felt "S. Darko" tried almost too hard to be like the first film and it had some almost predictable moments due to that. We know these films have that hidden Sci-Fi time travel aspect, but this time its almost just mushed into the story rather than unraveled out again...(one of my big complaints is that it takes Donnie extensive brain blows to figure out how to make time travel work and yet in this one it seems like child's play and anyone can do it). 

Bringing back Ms. Chase as S. Darko was a pretty sick move and considering how well she pulled off this film I was thoroughly impressed. as for most of the other parts, they were done well but not to the high expectations this man had. I wanted them to delve more into the Preacher character and explain that sub plot a wee bit more but I understand that they probably didn't have the budget to fully flesh that one out. Otherwise props to Ms. Chase for a job well done.

I have to say that I did enjoy this film quite a bit. Being a "Donnie Darko" fan from the beginning (before it blew up and went all Hot Topic and shit!) this did fill my craving for some more wacky hidden Sci Fi work. It was far more clever of a sequel then I was expecting and here's to hoping they make a few more that deliver like this one did!

S. Darko has the look and feel of Donnie Darko. I liked how the story was both a logical followup, plus a fresh reversal of Donnie Darko's personal time travel predicament. Woefully, the execution could've been much better. None of the characters and ideas were fleshed out well enough. I didn't care enough about the characters to grieve their sacrifice; I wasn't moved to tears like I was at the end of Donnie Darko. Some characters were downright annoying and some unbelievable. What was with the geeky meteorite-boy; was he influenced by the space rock or was he always a creep? (BTW - nice Jeff Goldblum impression!)  Recklessly, there were too many characters and storylines tossed around -  and not enough connective plotting to tie everything together like the masterpiece original. I liked some of the subtle references to the first Darko, but others were curiously forced; like the metallic rabbit mask and the Time Travel book. Worst thing of all was the setting was no longer in the magical 80's, so they played 1995 tunes; which took me out of the serious moments.

i can't really make heads or tails of this movie. there are parts where it channels donnie darko quite interestingly, such as the construction of the "frank the bunny" mask by iraq jack, and the whole double voice thing was cool. but then there are parts where it tries WAY too hard to be just like its predecessor, such as the exact same quotes from the first (4 days/13 hours/26 minutes/5 seconds) and the addition of the transparent "point of view" thing. then there are parts where i couldn't figure out what in the world was going on. i will attempt to explain....so there's sam darko (daveigh chase who was also sam darko in the first movie) who is donnie's little sister. she runs away from home with her best friend corey and go on a pointless road trip that leads them to break down in the middle of nowhere. enter randy, stereotypical bad boy who helps them fix their car. in the meanwhile, they mingle with the townfolk who obviously have never seen teenage girls. after this, the movie takes a turn for the worst. it just introduces new characters and doesn't attempt to give depth or backstory to any of them. and what's worse, is at the end, they do a collage featuring every person in the movie including them. then random dreams plague everyone in the town, revealing that either sam is dead or some kid is dead or whatever the heck is going on. then sam gets killed and the movie decides that the story should not end that way. so instead corey is killed by the car, but wait! there's more! the story still isn't satisfied. so it ends with them all being ok. i really don't know how to interpret this movie at all. it's just very bizarre, and nothing like the masterpiece that was the original. i think the filmmaker just wanted to cash in on a great movie by making a lame sequel.

Alright, where to begin?

First of all, this movie tries so hard to be as strange and odd as Donnie Darko, but fails so hard in every way imaginable. Instead of capturing the feeling of the first one, it just ends up blatantly copying it, and doesn't even copy it well (if that's even possible). They make allusions to the first film, but it's more for the sake of having the audience be like, "oh, hey, i remember that!" than having an actual reason for them.

The dialogue is atrocious. The actors might be reading the script for the first time from cue cards off screen. The plot is ludicrous. This movie just shouldn't exist. Plain and simple. I can't think of another movie more undeserving of a sequel. Let alone a sequel that's just a huge obstrocity.

The only reason it gets even half of a star is the fact that the Joaquin Phoenix look-alike said a line that reminded me of On a Boat by The Lonely Island, and said another line that reminded me of Optimus Prime from the Transformers cartoon.  Lines I'm talking about:
"That's about as real as it gets."
"I wish I could believe that."

At one point, I was like, "Oh good, the movie's over." But then I checked the time and it was only halfway through.  I think the only appropriate way to describe my feelings of this movie is:

An okay movie on its own, but as the unnecessary follow-up to Donnie Darko that is is?  Eh.  If this movie was its own thing with its own story, and handled properly, it could have been a really interesting and creepy tale... but trying to ride the heels of a film like Donnie Darko just had everything going against it.  On one hand the movie didn't really look like a low-budget STD movie... on the other hand, the acting was abominable.  Yeah, Daviegh Chase resumed her role from the original, and maybe the director WANTED her to act this way, but she basically just irritated me more than anything.  In all honestly, the style used by nearly everyone in this movie could have worked if they just took a little bit more time to nail it... but in the end it just felt rushed.  As for the story... well... I'm not entirely sure what was going on.  It was convoluted and tried too much to be like its predecessor that it ended up just being confusing.  Just because it's a sequel doesn't mean you have to tell me the same story with a few changes here and there.  And don't take that as a spoiler to this movie's ending.  When you see it, you'll understand.

7 years ago we were left with one of the biggest cliffhangers of all time. For years fans demanded a sequel and here it is. Well, OK, nobody wanted this and yet here it is. One of the most pointless and unwanted films to ever be made. In a way I feel kind of sorry for it. The film plays it too safe, simply imitating it's older brother. The idea of showing the film from the point of view of the manipulated dead as opposed to the living receiver is a good one. But apparenlt no matter what you are it's all a load of bollocks. The film is painfully dull and far too serious. Donnie Darko had an expert and hilarious sense of humour. There's no Sparkle Motion or "Suck a fuck"'s here. Donnie remained intriguing, due to expertly crafted websites and supplementary material, as well as a complex, but focused screenplay. S.Darko just misses the point, but doesn't even have the decency to be so bad, that's it's disgusting.

*moment of silence* I'm not too sure where I should begin here. I know! I'll start with a question.: "WHY IN THE WORLD WOULD DONNIE DARKO NEED A SEQUEL!?!?!?!?!?!?" The way the original Donnie Darko film ended, there was no room or need  for a sequel. How do you have "a Donnie Darko tale" without Donnie Darko? This movie, as I'm sure you can tell by the title, is strictly about his younger sister, Samantha. Who cares about what Samantha is doing all these years later? (I KNOW I don't!) Secondly, this film doesn't even have the same director, I was just fine with Richard Kelley's film. Now that I've stated those two reasons, let's look at the other problems with this "movie". These other problems are what told me this movie was going to be a waste of my time before I even put in my DVD player. The first thing is pretty obvious, the fact that this movie went straight to DVD is a pretty good sign that it sucks. Secondly, let's look at the fact that two of the cast members, that I know of, are from The CW (James Lafferty from One Tree Hill and Ed Westwick from Gossip Girl). I don't know about everyone else, but the only place that I want to see CW "actors" is on the CW. I?m sure this movie was made strictly to get money from the ?die-hard? fans of the original, PLEASE DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY!  By now, it should be pretty evident that I'm not a fan of this movie. The only reason that this filth is getting an entire star from me is simply because they didn't take an extra step in the wrong direction and hire a different actress to play the younger sister. Alone, it's just a bad movie, but when you compare it to the original I vomit a little. Donnie Darko was great the way it was, they should have left it alone. I hope this garbage doesn't spawn a bunch of other sequels to other films that ended right the first time. Next, they'll be trying to make a sequel to  Fight Club or Titanic or Taxi Driver...ridiculous!
BORING!  Seriously boring.. the first was sooo good, there was no way this could even live up to part of the hype.. the acting was horrible.. it was all around just not good.

If you enjoyed Donnie Darko, don't see this movie. 

If you got really into the concept and theories behind the Donnie Darko universe and read the book "Philosophy of Time Travel," you'll probably want to protect those you love and burn all copies of this movie so that others won't have the possibility to make the mistake of seeing it. 

As you might've guessed, Richard Kelly had nothing to do with this movie, something I think he should be making a bit more public right now. The only two things in common were the same producer (Adam Fields, which, you know, means everything) and, although I don't imagine it makes much of a difference, the original Samantha Darko actress (Daveigh Chase).

To sell the rights to his masterpiece (Donnie Darko) was an interesting move on Kelly's part though. Usually you'd think that someone would play the concerned artist and bury the rights alongside them in their grave to avoid any unwelcome additions to his beautiful creation. Instead, Kelly sold the rights to the great Chris Fisher, which is actually a clever move considering now he has maybe 20 bucks in his pocket AND he's insured that there will never again be a Donnie Darko spinoff. Just for fun, here's a little bit about Fisher:
   -Fisher is a USC law graduate who went to work as a corporate lawyer in London before deciding    
   to get into the entertainment industry. 
   -His resumé boasts directing two episodes of Moonlight (cancelled) and an episode of Chuck    
    (likely to soon be cancelled. 
   -He also directed a couple of direct-to-DVD horror movies. 
   -He looks like a total douche.

Yes, things can only go well for this movie. 

Now, I can carry on with the review, talk about the strained efforts of the other young actors who you can tell were baited with the thought "Oh boy! I loved Donnie Darko! This is going to be decent!" Or I could talk about how the "writer" (Nathan Atkins) has an unprecedented IMDB profile by being credited as an editor or sound guy NINE TIMES MORE THAN BEING CREDITED FOR WRITING ANYTHING. Fun fact: Of his writing credit power trio, one is S. Darko, one is a made-for-TV movie (Point of Entry), and the other is a short horror film that he directed. 

But really, just don't see this film. By giving into your curiosity about what happened afterwards in any movie that you enjoy, you're only creating a market for these abominations to exist. Remember: there are people PROFITING off of things like "American Pie 8: We Still Have A Closet Full Of Immature Humor To Share With You" and the animated Star Wars...[I]thing[/I]...that came out a while ago. Please, stand up for consumer rights and just say no. We're counting on you.

2.) plot... they had alot of pointless sub-plots going on... ironically some of them actually have potential (if they a willing to go further in developing them) ...but no they have to open them up and then slam that door shut... 
3.) huge plot holes... or let's just say continuity mistakes... things that they just wanna throw in there and claim that it came from the Donnie movie just for the heck of it (y Frank the bunny face? how did they get the book if Donnie had "fixed it" in the first movie?)
4.) alot of random things that would just make u say wtf... such as the freaking feather... or the one incident where the "ghost" can interact with the physical world directly (the "prison/jail breaking" part)
5.) trying too hard to b a "sequel" and made it look like a bad fan fic gone wild project... nothing original at all... meh
6.) etc etc

1.5 stars for not being absolutely i wanna shoot myself type of boring... and nice cinematography...
what a waste of John Hawkes talent... he only had like 2 mins screen time and he did do pretty well with those scenes...
if u a a fan of the original... plz don't watch this...

"Donnie Darko" is one of my favorite movies so when I heard they were making a direct-to-DVD sequel, I was intrigued, but knew it was going to be pure crap. The sequel tries to hold some kind of mystery and vibe from the original and it did keep my attention, but there is nothing original about this movie. You can totally predict the outcome because it borrows everything from the first movie. There are so many similarities, it makes you wonder if they just tried to mimick every single plot line. It was funny to see Jessie Spano in the movie and to see how "The Ring" girl has grown up.

This movie was okay if you weren't comparing it to the original.  It wasn't as dark, abstract, & interesting as Donnie Darko was.  Donnie Darko should have been left alone as a great cult classic without a sequel riding on it's coat tails.

As far as direct to DVD sequels to cult genre flicks without any of the returning talent (minus Daveigh Chase) go, this isn't so bad I guess.

It feels more like a bad cover of Donnie Darko than a sequel (and the random connections to the first movie are laughable - especially a bizarre, tacked on family connection).  Someone's taken everything that people liked about the first movie and basically moved it into another one without really understanding why people enjoyed the first one to begin with. 

So, there's weird rabbit masks, objects falling from the sky, countdowns, pillars of the community with dark secrets, arson, and even a repeat of the final slow motion every-character-contemplating-things montage. 

Except, there's no characters to root for, dialogue that's weird instead of mysterious, no real surprises for those who've seen the first movie (although there's one kind of cool twist midway through), and supporting characters who really don't have much to do.

A few scenes have some impact, but mostly it's been there, done that.... except for the space virus.... seriously... there's a space virus.

I did enjoy S. Darko very much. The imagery and music set a beautiful and mysterious dreamlike mood.

Instead of repeating the same plot of the orginial Donnie Darko the sequel looks at a Tangent Universe from other persons point of view. 

The Elements of the original Philosophy of Time Travel like the Manipulated Dead, the Living Receiver and of course the Artifact are all there again.

A great film for all those who still remember the rules of the first film and enjoy to play around with them in their head one more time.
If Flixster gave me the option to give this negative 5 stars, I totally would.
I just want to confirm... S. Darko was indeed a bad movie. At least we know Daveigh Chase grew up to be hot.
Obvious cash grab of a sequel that's technically proficient but lacks both a decent script and the spark of creativity that the original had.
HUGE disappointment. Came in not expecting much, got even less.

Clearly not Donnie Darko...but let's all be adults and not judge it solely based on it's rightful place in the Donnie Darko universe.

If you can't do that then you have no business reviewing movies for other people to see.

This was not a terrible movie by any means. It did take the DD concept and use it far too much...and the end with certain characters and events were a bit silly.

Overall it was intriguing and entertaining, what more can I ask for?
Why the hell was this ever made? Even the name sucks. S. Darko, really? Hey lazy ass writers, didn't manage to come up with a decent name?

Wow, what a huge letdown. The film Donnie Darko was unique, surreal, imaginative, edgy, and most of all original. This is just a sad excuse of a sequel story that has you scratching your head more often than not. It tries way too hard to be weird & surreal and just doesn't get the job done. It's not at all engaging, interesting, or thrilling. The story, acting and dialogue are all piss poor. Not much more I can say, ha ha. A shame really, as I was really looking forward to seeing this movie.

.I love, adore and worship Donnie Darko, it's my all time favorite movie; beautiful, emotional, innovative and simply - great..
with that being sad i was absolutely against the sequel, anyone who saw DD knows that the movie doesn't need any sequel, prequel, re-make or anything like that, it was all about the money, something like milking the dead golden cow while it was still breathing..and that's hollywood, i know..it's fu&$#%/ disgusting..
.so i put all that aside, being the fan of DD, having some principals and all that, and tried to see S. DARKO objectively, and the movie is simply BAD..and that's a rock solid fact..
it's really really bad, like i-threw-a-little-in-my-mouth-while-trying-to-watch-it bad..it doesn't have anything going for it..it's so painfully unoriginal, story so very boring, you can't tell which of the actors did the worse job (actually i would say that untalented guy from One Tree Hill), all the recognizable DD stuff (like frank's mask, frank's creepy voice sound, countdown to the end of the world, sleepwalking, camera movements, 80-music, tangent universe scheme, r. sparrow....... and countless of other similar copy/pastes.....) just thrown into the scenes with no sense, order or meaning but to make it look as much Donnie Darkish as possible, you can't relate and don't care for any of the characters..i mean, this is really bad..
.thing about it, there's got to be a reason why this went straight to dvd when there's so much bad and lousy movies out there, but still bringing in the money on box-office..well, i didn't pay for SD so i'm not that miserable, but i am going to punch myself once in the stomach for spending an hour and a half watching it and once in the face for taking 5min out of my time (which i have a lot, btw) to write this..yea, it's that bad..

i don't know what to make of it, it's nothing like the first....i liked how they expanded the whole mythology but it didn't feel like the original. two key differences was the look and the other was the music. The do overs are something that kind of got me scratching my head on how to feel about this flick. but this is just my initial feeling, maybe i'll update this and i can make more sense of things in the future....like a do over

I made myself sit through a movie I never ever wanted to lay eyes on. And I should have stayed away from it. It wasn't bad as a seperate stand-alone movie, but as a sequel to Donnie Darko, it was a horrendous mess. Why they made a sequel is beyond me. Donnie Darko left us with one of the greatest cliffhangers of all time..."What happens next?" And then comes along S. Darko. It would have been fine as a stand-alone movie as I said before, the writers just had to change character names, take out the wormholes and all the talk about manipulated living and the tangent universe, then hooray we have ourselves a completely different movie. Daveigh Chase isn't nearly as good of a lead as Jake Gyllenhaal in Donnie Darko. A huge dissappointment, and just a piece of crap when compared to Donnie. No memorable dialogue in S. Darko whatsoever, no great scenes like the family dinner in Donnie Darko, little to no suspense at all, and acting that will make you cringe from how bad it is. Stay away from this one.

It's really not as bad as everyone says it is. It's no Donnie Darko, but aside from that i thought it was beautiful. The cinematography and the general tone of it I loved. I'm not about to praise the dialogue though, i believe "Gnarly" was used once. The parallels between this and Donnie Darko also spoilt it for me as they became a little annoying and repetitive. But aside from that, i really liked it.  Although it is innevitably compared to D.D, to fully appreciate it, you need to take it out of context, and notice it for its individuality as a film.

They always take the sequels to far. This movie tried way to hard to be like Donnie Darko.  Of course in a situation like this one you can't exactly win - either it is to much like the first one or to different and fans of the first movie hate it.  I think that this movie stood a better chance being a stand alone movie, but considering that you can't have another Darko movie that has nothing to do with the first it will never get away from the comparison.

"s. Darko" is the sequel to the cult hit "Donnie Darko". The story picks up seven years after the first film when little sister Samantha Darko and her best friend Corey are now 18 and on a roadtrip to Los Angeles when they are plagued by bizarre visions.

"s. Darko" isn't a bad movie and it presents some interesting ideas, but the major flaw in this is that it is too faithful to "Donnie Darko". It's actually so faithful that the movie feels more like a rehash than a sequel. With some script revisions this could of been something great, but instead, settles for good. 

Just like "Donnie Darko", "s. Darko" has an amazing soundtrack and score. Ed Harcourt has composed an unforgettable score and the 90's based songs they have chosen goes fantastically with the overall feel of the movie. The acting is also superb as is the cinematography.

Wow. Just...wow.  I'll admit that I had a smidge of hope when I heard of this movie. As a fan of Richard Kelly's amazingly mesmerizing first cinema outing, Donnie Darko, I was intrigued that someone even had the balls to want to move the story forward. But the story doesnt do anything. It's a spastic, boring mess.

With the exception of the character of Iraq Jack (who is unarguably the film's best character in the movie  in my opinion) I found it hard to like any of the other characters including Samantha Darko, the movie's titular chracter.

While trying to capitalize on what made Donnie Darko so great the film falls short by trying so hard to homage the movie.

Red Car, liquid spears, artifacts falling from the sky, burning something to the ground while sleepwalking, the book written by Roberta Sparrow, etc etc etc....

This movie may have been well if they had opted for a more original plot. 

One user on here reviewed it as watching some D. Darko fan's lame fan fiction come to life...and that's a very true statement. 

It makes me wish I could drop a plane engine on the head of the people involved in the making of this movie.

I was suprised they would make a sequal to a movie like Donnie Darko but I gave it a chance thinking it would be somewhat as good as the original. This would have been a good movie if it hadnt swayed away from the original and made it so it seemed that everyone had to power to see the future and there were just to many other things going on that werent really needed. It just made the movie seem really forced and I just didnt enjoy as much.
